Here is not an easy subject to talk about, the human cruelty is something we all suffer from at some time of our life but don't apply a scientific explanation into the concept. Simon Baron-Cohen talks about the lack of empathy as a main ground for evil. He goes inside the brain and brings neuroscience to explain why some people have a zero degree of empathy. The author talks about different personality types and disorders such as autism, Asperger syndrome, bipolar disorder, narcissistic brain and the mind of the psychopath. Even if all of them are at the end of the spectrum of empathy there is a vast difference in these conditions. It is a very interesting book that gives us better understanding of human nature and the work of mind.

3.5/5 stars but rounded up as I'm in a charitable mood. This is very readable, and in its way very plausible, but this "new theory" is sorely lacking in cultural/social perspective. I guess if we view humans as these little machines that can be programmed in particular ways then we might find this convincing. Cohen makes some mention of twin studies, he admits that the "nature versus nurture" argument hasn't quite been resolved yet, he hedges some of his claims, but I think that he thinks he has stumbled across something that no one else had quite figured out properly (hence the "new") and this intellectual arrogance shows - one senses that "theory" was used begrudgingly in the subtitle. Nevertheless this is a very good read and the empathy scale was especially interesting.

The Science of Evil: On Empathy and the Origins of Cruelty by Simon Baron-Cohen is a mildly interesting examination on the connections between empathy and personality disorders, including psychopathy. The reason I say "mildly" interesting is that there is very little that is surprising although the book is easy to read and the case histories of interest. The science itself was of less interest to me.

A fascinating book about the origins of evil. Simon Baron-Cohen (the brother of comedian Sasha Baron-Cohen, for those interested) explores the science of evil, and finds that environmental factors in early childhood results in the maldevelopment of the empathy centers in the brain. Those with serious mental illnesses like Borderline, Narcissistic, and Antisocial Personality Disorders, simply are unable to project themselves into the place of another person. They are hyper-ego focused because they cannot mentally put themselves in another person's shoes. The research is solid, but presented in an engaging style that keeps the attention.

I'm confused about how this author can talk about the people he is studying as having 'zero degrees of empathy' when the manner in which he speaks is so devoid of any empathy towards his patients / subjects. His descriptions of people with borderline personality disorder in particular, or 'borderlines' as Baron-Cohen chooses to call them/us, is completely out of line with the rest of the recent literature on this subject. This is not because he has a unique ground-breaking insight, but rather because he is choosing to use stigmatising and false descriptions of this group of people which serve to reinforce negative stereotypes.

I'm giving this four stars because I think what Baron-Cohen has to say is very important, his research is fearless, and his willingness to follow his curiosity to unpopular ends should be supported. However, aside from a shocking beginning (i.e., with examples of Nazi evils--sorry, negative Zero-Empathy Nazi acts), this book is definitely about the science and a tad dry. Perhaps I just get enough of it at work, but discussions of the roles of the different areas of the brain in empathy did not hold my interest very well. He's a fine writer but could have used a better editor.

Simon Baron-Cohen asks the reader to look scientifically at "evil," and to see it as a lack of empathy caused by deficits in the "empathy circuit" of our brains. I found it very interesting to learn about different sections of the brain that work together to create feelings of empathy. Baron-Cohen argues that empathy is humanity's greatest asset, and that more effort needs to be put into cultivating empathy in children. I feel smarter having read this book!

The author gives a provisional scientific explanation for human cruelty as a lack of empathy, rather than as the moral category of evil, so that it can be studied and analyzed. He describes what he terms negative zero-empathy (sociopath, narcissist, borderline) and positive zero-empathy (autism spectrum) as well as possible neurological causes. I found the content not as important as the attempt at an empirical analysis of what is usually considered simply moral failure.

this book was good in the fact that it places evil which the author claims is an immesurable trait in terms or morality. Which is measurable. It then puts it into application and practice on real situations/cases of lack of morality, or evil behaviors. A lot of it is brain based physiological science which is very interesting. I found this book informative and very understandable.

I only ready 1/3 of this book before giving up. I wanted to mark it as read in case I thought about reading it again. Don't do it Jeannette! It's not about evil, but about different levels of empathy. It was a dry, super sciencey book that a doctor might enjoy, but not for consumption by the average Joe.

Interesting findings from the point of view of neuroscience. It is a nice companion to Roy Baumeister's 
Evil: Inside Human Violence and Cruelty
.

This was a very interesting read - with some very disturbing and upsetting bits in it - as you would expect form a book exploring human cruelty. Although a theoretical book, it is written in an approachable form; I found myself reading this both on the way to and back from work; the theory and clinical vocabulary did not put me off.

The melodrama is taken out of the word evil and empathy is measured in the neurological and the biochemical workings of the brain. This removes much of our tendency to recoil from those who are low in or devoid of empathy and allows us a more objective study of the brain and its relationship to character.

I bought this book two days ago and have almost finished it. Compelling look at the biological and environmental reasons behind human cruelty and kindness. Especially positive take on the ability of people who have autism or aspergers to still act in kind and moral ways, despite lacking a theory of mind. Loving this read.

I found this books and some of the ideas interesting. Yet evil is always a mysterious abyss, we map the edges, measure the depth but we still don't understand why it exists. It was both telling and tragic that I finished this book on the day that man killed 27 people who were simply gathering to pray and gather. We sift thru clues but we will never really know why.

I read this book and against empathy by Paul Bloom for comparison since both are opposite side the coin. I prefer this one more and I found it more profound than it counter part. You could also read follow up article on boston review as well

Even though this wasn't exactly what I expected, it was exactly what should be written about evil.It is a real eye-opener. The subtitle is more accurate. It is about understanding empathy and the origins of cruelty with the stress on CRUELTY. Hitler was one of many. I didn't like knowing this but sometimes the truth hurts. And it needs to be told.I highly recommend this read.

This was a very interesting book. I found the definitions of the personality types very fascinating, I did find the medical definitions of the brain a bit hard to follow.If you are interested in the why of cruelty this is a good read even though it doesn't answer the question.

This book has provided me profound insights through various illustrations of human behaviours. Its helping me to empathize with people better and looking at the other side of the perspective and what led someone to behave the weird way which you never liked.
Good, but I don't feel anything revolutionary was discussed here.
Much more technical than I was expecting but an interesting look at the relationship between empathy (or lack thereof) and evil acts.
Author makes a solid argument for empathy & is mindful to explain different reasons people may lack empathy. Presents the problem, but doesn't address or give ideas for solutions.
Sexy title for scholarly work which says some people have a screw loose.
Loved the way the author attempts to approach the problem of evil objectively. A true eye-opener!
Nothing earth shattering here. Interesting, but a bit redundant and off topic. Never discussed the origins of cruelty. In fact, this book was all about empathy and what is and isn't.
Interesting. Though my social work sister disagreed with some of the terminology I quoted. I liked the part about genes in the circuit being wrong the best.
A fascinating and fairly quick read.
A fascinating study of human interaction explained in such a way that even a non-specialist like me can follow everything!
An interesting and accessible examination of empathy and the lack thereof in people from a scientific point of view.
Excellent book but if you are new to psychology, it might be a bit hard-going.
A quick read (by Sasha Baron-Cohen's cousin!) the effectively makes the case that conversations about evil need to be reframed as discussions about lack of empathy.
Some excellent theories, but needs more concrete examples from science and less personal speculation
This was an interesting read, albeit a little dry.
It had some interesting points but it wasn't captivating.
Cannot finish the book and suggest others don’t bother. Lost faith in the knowledge of the author after he claimed that those with BPD are cruel with no empathy.
Way too fluffy, way too many vague overgeneralizations.
Very thought-provoking and provides another way to understand "evil."
ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT BOOK.NEED MORE.

Simon Baron Cohen’s fundamental idea is that in order to prevent evil we must first understand its causes. How was Josef Fritzl capable of locking up his own daugter in his basement and then rape her on a daily basis for more than a decade? The typical reaction to this type of story is that Josef Fritzl is an evil man, and he did what he did because he was evil. But what does it mean when you say that someone is evil, and does deeming someone as an evil person have any positive side effects? These are of course difficult questions and I don’t think that Baron Cohen provides a complete answer to them (which would have been a lot to hope for). What Baron Cohen does claim is that if we want to prevent evil we must first understand it. He further suggests that individuals, such as Fritzl, who commit horrendous acts probably suffers from a lack of empathy, that is a lacking ability to see the world from another persons perspective. Borderline patients, psychopaths and narcissists are three mental disorders that have a common feature, namely zero empathy. In other words they are more or less incapable of seeing the world from another persons perspective and therefore they may not get the same “gut response” when they hear about Fritzl. Many people lack empathy, but not all of them endorse in “evil”. Other factors such as upbringing and attachments to caregivers can influence whether a person born with deficient empathy becomes an offender or learns how to follow the rules of society despite lacking some of the intuitions that derives from having empathy. Simon Baron Cohen’s expertize lies in the field of autism which is another mental dissorders characterized by a lack of empathy. Individuals that have a autism spectrum dissorder (this category includes those with asperger syndrome), also behave in ways that reveal a lack of empathy, however, they are often good at systematizing, that is seeing relationships between various variables in the world. Because of this special ability they have benefited the world in many waysRather than deeming individuals evil, we should try to understand why evil acts are committed. To look at people with a severe lack of empathy is a good and plausibly fruitful starting point for such an endeavour. Simon Baron Cohen, is a terrific writer with the ability to convey complex ideas and complex research findings in an accessible and easy to understand way. This book as well as “The essential difference” show that this is indeed the case.

The alarming part for me of this book was that he says 1% of the population have zero empathy - that is in a population of 60 million 60,000 people - a lot! (At first I thought it was 600,000 until I re-did my maths, phew).Admittedly most of those 60,000 wouldn't commit violence because there is no reason for them to do so, but I imagine a fair number abuse their partners or have the potential to inflict great cruelty if the circumstance was right.I have a relative who I realise now fell into the borderline personality category - she had a chaotic life, always acting with great selfishness but punishing herself even more than wreaking everyone's lives around her (she eventually committed suicide). I always had the sense that part of her brain was missing, that somehow the empathetic part just wasn't there. She could be incredibly charming and good company but utterly selfish. Maybe if I had understood her better I might have been more sympathetic.The book clarified for me many factors which I have suspected for a long while - namely the fact that empathy is primarily genetic but there is a strong link between empathy and childhood. That the brain is an organ like any other organ, it may be monstrously complicated but it is physically shaped by the environment around it, in particular at the time of its development. I really liked the graphic at the end outlining the 12 factors affecting empathy, ranging from the physical (alcohol intake etc), neurological, genetic, anger and emotions (which I suppose runs under the category of hormones) to tribal, the in group/out group influences, childhood etc. Fascinating. And big implications for society as a whole - for instance cracking down on domestic violence could have the side effect of bringing down violent crime, what effect does war have on the children who have to live through it? And how can we help them?As a side note when my Mum suffered from dementia, she in no way ever lacking in empathy, but you could see parts of her brain dying - so she, who all her life had been careful about what she would say, was suddenly passing rude comments to people in supermarkets, which I suppose reflects one of Baron-Cohen's neurological trigger points malfunctioning. Horrible to see but again confirming the physical nature of the brain. We are just another mammal.

The book begins** ..."When I was seven years old, my father told me the Nazis had turned Jews into lampshades. Just one of those comments that you hear once, and the thought never goes away. To a child’s mind (even to an adult’s) these two types of things just don’t belong together. He also told me the Nazis turned Jews into bars of soap. It sounds so unbelievable, yet it is actually true. I knew our family was Jewish, so this image of turning people into objects felt a bit close to home. My father also told me about one of his former girlfriends, Ruth Goldblatt, whose mother had survived a concentration camp. He had been introduced to the mother and was shocked to discover that her hands were reversed. Nazi scientists had severed Mrs. Goldblatt’s hands, switched them around, and sewn them on again so that if she put her hands out palms down, her thumbs were on the outside and her little fingers were on the inside. Just one of the many ‘experiments’ they had conducted. I realized there was a paradox at the heart of human nature—people could objectify others—that my young mind was not yet ready to figure out. […] Today, almost half a century after my father’s revelations to me about the extremes of human behavior, my mind is still exercised by the same, single question: How can we understand human cruelty."Well, do you believe the stories about the lampshade, the soap, the switching of hands? The lampshade and soap stories have been abandoned altogether by serious Holocaust scholars, and Mrs. Goldblatt's story is preposterous, and as far as I know there is zero actual evidence for it. ** The 2012 edition modified the above text, to see the original (as above) see https://archive.org/details/SimonBaro...

I listened the audiobook, so it was hard to follow all abbreviations of genes. I wish the book had more stories or examples instead of dry scientific language. I was thinking to give three stars. Then, one statement of the author threw me off completely. In Chapter 6, the author mentions Adolph Hitler and then continues. “No one, however evil we paint them to be, should be treated as 100% bad or is beyond responding to a humane approach. The questions is whether we can push this notion to the logical conclusion. If unambiguously evil individuals, a candidate for this category might be Hitler, felt remorse for their and had been punished, would we try to focus on their good qualities with an intent to rehabilitate them. My own view is that we should do this no matter how bad their crime. It is the only way we can establish that we are showing empathy to the perpetrator, not just repeating a crime of turning the perpetrator into an object and thus dehumanizing them. But doing that we are no better than the person we punish.”Seriously?! We should have tendered 0.00000001% good in Hitler, so he would blossom as “the flower in the desert”? Then, the author talks about Ronnie Lee Gardner and how he was executed by a firing squad. I looked up the info for Gardner. He killed one man in robbery in 1984. In April 1985, while being moved to the court for his homicide hearing, he killed the attorney. In 1994, he stabbed his fellow inmate. Fortunately, the inmate survived. Then, the author raves how police officers could shoot this unarmed man tied to the chair. I guess if the author thinks that Hitler deserved the rehabilitation...... So only one star for this nonsense ending of the book.

i think a lot of people would say they enjoyed this book, that it was insightful. i respectfully disagree: i could write a paper on why this book is harmful or upsetting to read (and i have) but i'll just sum it down to one thing:the work surprisingly lacks an ability to form an argument, especially one concerning "definition" and "concept": this is because baron-cohen clearly has a pretty lacking understanding of what it means to write philosophy in the post-analytic era. his lack of respect for the field shows: he calls "evil" "religious," although there has been a long conversation in ethics and philosophy about the use of the term "evil" to denote things !!!!! not one paper ON conceptual ethics is cited. it's almost like watching a physicist walk into med school and start acting like he knows everything about everything, and upon repeating some filler mumbo-jumbo, deciding that he's reinvented the dicipline.the book doesn't need to exist, and it carries with it a surprising lack of empathy for people with borderline personality disorder and difficulty empathizing. its model of "empathy" fails to meet up to the standards of intuitive, daily experience, and the argumentative vigor required of conceptual analysis is not respected, and his scientific discourse does not line up or successfully support the emotional, literary discourse he wishes to lead to a conclusion.the work reads like a mediocre book about the pathology of empathy driven HEAVILY by the publishers to restructure its framework for SEO and casual audiences. it's a book written for the book deal, and while i'm glad baron-cohen is making bank, i guess, i really would like him to stray away from philosophical discourse unless he wants to actually read the discourse next time.

It's not a revolutionary study. Indeed, I will call it incremental science at best.Baron-Cohen provides a novel perspective to look at evil/cruelty. He believes that "loss of empathy" underlies every horrific human acts that have been/will be committed. He explores the lower extreme of "empathy spectrum", suggesting that this group (of lower/nil empathy) can be subdivided to personalities such as borderline (B), narcism (N), psychopath (P), and zero-positive (systemizer). As one who does not have any psychology background, to learn about these categorization is a fun. Cohen points out that biological factors (genetics) as well as environmental factors (ideology, culture, and childhood experiences) contributes to permanent loss of empathy. Emotion can cause temporary loss. His argument is solid and well supported.When Baron-Cohen moves to suggest how we should treat individuals with zero empathy who committed crimes, his argument becomes weaker. I assume Cohen is not trained in ethics, and his perspective is a typical for middle class, liberal, well educated and no big events (e.g. close friends/relatives being hurt by psychopaths). Who should be hold responsible if criminals who luckily reversed their zero empathy and are given a second chance committed serious crime again? It's highly likely given their predisposition. "Sorry for your loss" and "it's just bad luck" do not seem enough for victim's family. When autonomy of an individual is in conflict with potential well beings of general public, who to sacrifice? Cohen mentioned before that this kind of moral situation is complex and hard to judge, then how can he voices out such suggestions at the end of his book?

This was a very interesting read although it was a little different than what I had expected. Because of the title, I was expecting something a little darker and more related towards the ideas of evil and the bad things that people do. However, Baron-Cohen's book is all about empathy. And to be honest, this was a very refreshing book on the ideas of "evil." Baron-Cohen is very adamant in clarifying his opinions and what they do or do not relate to and it's interesting to take his ideas and fit them into whatever thoughts you may have on your own. The more scientific chapters on neurology were a little dull if you don't have any prior experience with that field, but the rest of the book certainly makes up for it.I think Baron-Cohen's examples were the best part of the book. Each adage was taken from real events and used to express ideas that the author had in order to more easily relate them to the reader. There are examples of violence, but also examples of individuals with mental illness that may or may not contribute to acts of cruelty. That is not to say Baron-Cohen only focuses on the negative. On the contrary, he is very clear in identifying positive ways in which a lack of empathy can influence an individual (this was certainly one of the most interesting sections to me).Make sure you read until the end. To me, the last chapter (6) was the most interesting. This is where Baron-Cohen really takes all of his evidence and examples and sums it up into a nice conclusion.Definitely would recommend this to anyone with an interest in psychology and how the human brain can justify or simply not understand acts of "evil."

I enjoyed this book. It was well organized and an easy read considering the complexity of the science (neurology and genetics). The author begins with a fairly simple hypothesis; if " you treat someone as an object, your empathy has been turned off" and that is the final pathway to cruelty. He starts by identifying an empathy circuit in the brain. Borderline, psychopaths, narcissists, autism and Asperger's are all conditions that show abnormalities in the empathy circuit and he looks at how people could develop these. There is a good amount of interesting information, like the differences between cognitive and affective empathy and the distinctions between the different disorders. The author also presents some original research where his team identified 4 genes associated with empathy. The thing I was disappointed in was how incomplete the book seemed. It doesn't come to many conclusions about committing cruel acts. After the build up of presenting the science of empathy, the author jumps around topics a bit, poses a few (thought provoking) questions and gives his opinions (which I enjoyed). The author states, "if I have successfully moved the debate out of the domain of religion and into the social and biological sciences, I will feel this book has made a contribution." I think the author made an important discovery in the genetics of empathy and he wanted to present his research, as well prompt others to begin investigation. It is not claiming to be a resolved topic. While that may be frustrating as a reader, I think the book did its job.

This book is talked about by many of the other authors I have read, so I thought I should check it out.Author Simon Baron-Cohen produces the thesis that empathy can be plotted on a Gaussian (or "bell curve") distribution, with most people falling somewhere in the middle, and psychopaths and the extremely empathetic occupying the tail ends of the distribution. The book also talks about narcissism, autism, antisocial disorder, and borderline personality disorder.Cohen rejects the orthodox thinking that "evil" exists as a pathology, and proposes that it is instead a lack of empathy; Seeing a person (or group of people) not as human beings, but objects. While his thesis is interesting, I found this book to be one of those unfortunate science books that are plagued by dry, arduous and long-winded writing. It could have done better with a more rigorous editing and formatting, in my opinion. Also, Cohen states his concern about a societal erosion of empathy in a few places in the book. I would argue that empathy in modern, western countries is trending the other way; towards a pathology. Paul Bloom covers a bit of this in his 2016 book "Against Empathy".While I found this book somewhat interesting, it could have been improved by a more engaging writing style.3 stars.

Instead of buying this book, here's all you need to know (it wasn't in the book): John Locke wrote a long time ago that when we see someone in pain, we also tend to feel pain. It's not the same pain, it's an emotional pain, and it causes us to stop the suffering or to avoid hurting people. This pain that we feel when we see or imagine pain plays a HUGE factor in our lives.It's an emotional response. This is, basically, what this author calls 'empathy' - the capacity to feel pain when we see pain. He doesn't say this because there's a lot of fuzzy, sentimental thinking in this book. There's a lot of filler material in this book.So 1) we tend to feel pain when we see pain. 2) When don't we feel pain when we see pain? This is the other thing you need to be able to think about. If the person suffering is not like you, you might not feel much pain when he/she suffers. If you can demonize the person, you might not feel pain when you see this type of person suffering.So basically the guy's argument is that we don't feel pain when we see people we don't like suffering, and this leads to the ability to engage in evil actions.There you go, now you can spend your hard-earned money on a better book.

Not really much new from the cousin of Sacha Baron Cohen. He covers the basics of the malignant personality types (cluster B), the supposed anatomical pathways and chemical mechanisms for experiencing empathy, and the purported causes get summarized briefly. Unfortunately, it only devotes about two sentences to the impact beliefs (narratives) have on behavior, which is surprising, because cognitive behavioral therapy actually has a decent track record in producing positive outcomes. If you are like me and looking for research that attempts less to locate and assign empathy to prescriptions (Baron Cohen suggests that the nasal spray emitting oxytocin is a promising breakthrough) while relegating emotions to measurements within a rigid scientific paradigm, but rather you prefer a discussion of innovative methods to improve perspectives, self-worth, etc. by teaching/encouraging empathy, then I would suggest Lewis Mehl-Madrona's "Healing the Mind through the Power of Story: The Promise of Narrative Psychiatry." There just didn't seem to be much to this book, especially the final discussion leaves one flat.

This is an okay book about how empathy works in the brain. Baron-Cohen is arguing that we should replace the idea of "evil"---which explains nothing about human nature---with the idea of zero empathy. People with borderline, antisocial, and narcissistic personality disorders have what he calls zero-negative empathy, which includes intentional cruelty and has no redeeming characteristics, while people on the autism spectrum have what he calls zero-positive empathy: they don't understand other people's emotions, but have no intent to harm, and their lack of empathy is (often) paired with increased pattern-recognition ability. I'm dubious about this descriptive schema, mostly because I feel like the gap between the autism spectrum and personality disorders is wider than he's trying to make it out to be (I also think he gets a little starry-eyed at the end, when he's talking about teaching empathy to psychopaths), but I think he's right that "zero empathy" is a more useful explanatory tool than "evil."Three stars.ETA 2020/03/01 The more I think about it, the less I like Baron-Cohen's ideas. Downgraded to two stars.

I had different expectations going into this book. I thought it would be more about how we view those who are evil and dissect varying meanings of evil. However, despite the book turning out to be an argument for why we should push the study of empathy, I was pleasantly surprised. Cohen uses many arguments for how empathy is developed and understood (environmental, genetic, etc) so I don't feel he is pushing a particular origin rather suggesting that empathy has a larger role in our lives than currently understood and that we need to continue to learn about it. I'd compare this book more so to a review on what we already know about some disorders and their relation to empathy and the development of new terminologies and frameworks could elucidate how we continue to think about those disorders and future ones. This book posits more ideas than concludes but I think if you're open minded to reading an opinion piece with substantial evidence to support it, it could be an interesting read.

Call it 2.5 stars.This book is okay but does not live up to the title, which is crafted to sell copies rather than accurately describe the content. In fact the author immediately disclaims the word "evil" and launches in with his hypothesis: that people do not do evil but commit acts during low points in their empathy. After laying this groundwork, we basically get the author's body of scientific research laid out for us as he describes in detail the various types of people with "zero degrees of empathy": borderlines, narcissists, and psychopaths. I've been a bit negative here, but if anything the reason is because I was disappointed in the content. The author talks a lot about extreme empathy disorders, and there are some very good nuggets of knowledge here. But I wanted more discussion about other degrees of empathy and also the impacts on society. We get just a little of that. The book is short; there's room for more, but the author didn't have more. Overall, the book just didn't deliver enough for me.

An interesting and convincing text that argues for the restructuring of how we use the word “evil”. The author urges readers to challenge the traditional religious/spiritual explanation for acts of cruelty. Deduction that such acts are just unexplainable serves no purpose in decoding the mentality behind the behavior.During the span of his research the author discusses a couple routes to which an individual may arrive at a state of empathy depletion. The presence of a personality disorder or autistic spectrum condition are the abnormalities which mark the erosion. Individuals characterized as zero negative develop the state of empathy erosion through the manifestation of personality disorders. Although this does not categorize all of the personality disorders that may cause one to experience empathy erosion. Borderline, narcissistic, and psychopathic personality disorders are rooted in egocentricity making it extremely difficult to empathize.In the following manifestation of empathy erosion, the author discusses individuals with autistic conditions particularly Aspergers Syndrome. The low states of empathy are compounded by the need for the autistic mind to systematize.

The book simplifies the world by making "Lack of empathy" as the root of all evil. The author underpins his argument on the dark triads - Borderline Personality Disorder, Psychopathy and Narcissism. He replaced Machiavellianism with BPD as he considers Machiavellianism as amateur Psychopathy! People with dark triad traits lack empathy and are mostly behind all the violence we see around the world. Author further adds that empathy can be learned and by effective rehabilitation program we can transform the criminals and can vastly reduce crimes and harsh punishments alike. These are outlandish claims. Additionally, The author doesn't mention about the positive effects of lacking empathy and negative effects of high empathy. Functional psychopaths are running the world by heading most of the NGOs as well as Private and Govt organizations. On the other hand, highly emphatic peoples are handicapped by pathological altruism. He completely ignored these facts, that's why I don't by his black and white world of Empathy.

It was good to read about what happens in the brain and that empathy or the lack of it shows up in at least ten regions of the brain. A good insightful read. This is a quote from the book--" But I should qualify the definition of empathy by adding that the point at which we objectify another person while simultaneously switching off our sensitivity to his emotions is the starting point toward zero degrees of empathy. It is not the end point because as we have seen in the catalog of crimes people commit, such a state of mind simply makes it possible to behave in more and more hurtful ways." This is a critical point because in society we see leanings toward dehumanization in the way we respond to others. I found myself asking, " In what ways do I objectify people?" As Martin Luther King said, " Hate cannot cast out hate. Only love can do that." Doesn't mean it always will or that there is never a time to stop evil with solid boundaries, but that it should be done in love.

If you're close to someone on the ASD spectrum, read this book, or at least to the end of chapter 4. I found this book surprisingly entertaining and not too technical, so I enjoyed it for the most part. However, I could have done without the author's naive political insights in the end. For example, he presents the Israeli-Palestinian "conflict" as an example which could be remedied "if only each community could see the other's point of view and empathize." You cannot call on both sides to have empathy for each other when one is actively oppressing the other. "Whatever the cause, the consequence has been 60 years....of human suffering" on both sides. When one of the two parties is occupied and dispossessed by the other, the cause is of utmost importance. He ends with "empathy cannot by definition oppress anyone." Actually, it can. Misplaced empathy can itself be a form of, or result in, oppression.

In this book, Simon Baron-Cohen makes an argument that evil is actually due to lack of empathy- an argument that I find hard to buy hook, line and sinker. Yet he does throw light on a lot of issue surrounding empathy, like the difference between cognitive and emotional empathy; the brain systems, environmental influences and genetic factors affecting empathy and his classification of zero negative and zero positive forms of empathy is interesting. I somehow still find it hard to club Narcissist, psychopaths and borderline as all having zero negative empathy deficit; his theory about Aspergers having zero positive empathy viz systematizing is more plausible and something that has stood the test of time. The writing flows easily and naturally and its a relatively short book, but with bulky notes and appendices. Overall worth reading and contemplating.

It’s a very well written book - easy to read, you don’t need any prior background on the matter and it gives you real life examples instead of a profile (I feel like profiling an hypothetical person can be compared to the zodiac signs - someone will eventually fit that description). Whether or not you agree with the author is beside the point and it shouldn’t affect its rating.The author starts by giving some examples what low or no empathy looks like. He proceeds to describe each profile and gives real life examples and, whenever possible I assume, an extra example of a known personality (as in famous person ahah). Hoje next chapter becomes more scientific, but no less interesting, with an explanation which areas of the brain are affected or not “switched on”.Don’t be put off by some of the reviews.. make up your own mind and read it.

This is one of those books that make you look like a psychopath on the bus. But it was a really great read. It does well to bring in the very sciency and technical parts quite gradually and even if you haven't taken all of that it in early chapters (which I didn't) it didn't matter too much while continuing through the book as it discusses other points e.g. personality types like psychopathy and narcissism, with portraits of people. It's surprisingly an easy and refreshing read. I also like that as a science book the author doesn't shy away from revealing parts of his personality or opinions on matters, particularly some of the morals and ethics of past research. It's short enough and enlightening enough that I would be hapy to re-read one afternoon.

If I had to sum this book up in a short sentence, it would be 'Strong on science, weak on Philosophy'. The book starts out badly by asserting that 'religion', presumably in this case the Judaeo-Christian tradition, holds that evil is a brute fact which is not capable of explanation. This simply isn't the case, and the fact that Baron-Cohen thinks this shows that he has spent literally no time at all investigating the matter; St Augustine's discussion of evil, just to pick an example, actually mirrors his own outlines of the 'zero-negative' types in many respects. Those discussions of evil which define evil as a brute and inexplicable malevolence are in fact discussions of a hypothetical 'pure evil' in which evil is unmixed with other normal emotions and motivations; in which a person would simply want to do things because they were bad, rather than out of a mistaken apprehension of the good. This idea follows from Aristotle's notion that people always aim to do what they think is good, but that evil people are often mistaken. Theologians are divided over whether such a category of evil even exists, so it certainly should not be seen as the main theological account of evil.The discussion of clinical evidence in the book is interesting, but unfortunately the persuasiveness of the whole work is continually undermined by these failures to do basic research, or by sheer philosophical naivety. Towards the end of the book, where Baron-Cohen is arguing for greater leniency towards certain kinds of criminals, and that the Israel Palestine conflict can be solved by a process of empathy, what he ignores is that justice is a separate analytical category from empathy. An Israeli empathising with Palestinians is not going to force them to conclude that the real rulers of the Israeli state ought to be Palestinians, or vice versa, but unfortunately, in cases such as the Israel-Palestine conflict, for many people involved, such a counter-factual situation is the only one which approximates justice. Empathy for someone's emotional state does not guarantee that you will agree with their assessment of the situation or the claims they make about their situation.Similarly, his argument that, even if certain offenders have diminished responsibility for their actions due to deficiencies in their neurological equipment for empathy, they still ought to be sentenced to lengthy jail-terms in order to protect the public and convey society's disapproval of their act ignores the central question of whether or not justice has been done, and pretends that justice can be boiled down to considerations of expediency.Furthermore, in several places he asserts that in order to commit certain kinds violent of acts, at that time, the person in question must be suffering a temporary empathy deficiency. This is just unpersuasive, demonstrating as it does very little awareness of the potential for internal conflict that characterises human life; surely we know that sometimes people do terrible things with their empathy intact, precisely because they feel that there is some more important principle at stake.As in many works of pop-science, it is when the philosophical conclusions are being drawn that the narrative falls apart. Baron-Cohen seems doubtful, for example, about the existence of free-will, but nevertheless thinks we should keep it part of our conceptual vocabulary because it is a useful regulatory concept. He does not even address the many issues that such a stance raises, such as what use a fiction can have in informing justice; surely if we don't really have free will, no one is responsible for anything, and in fact, it doesn't matter whether our punishments are harsh or lenient; we are all simply following the inevitable chain of events. Free will isn't just a matter of choice, it is a concept upon which ideas like 'meaning', 'fairness', 'responsibility', and 'justice' depend. It can't simply be kept around if it isn't true, or more accurately, it makes no moral difference whether we keep it around or not; we are not responsible for our actions.It's books like this that make you wish scientists would just stick to the science.

One of those books you pick up because the cover looks both intimidating and seductive, and then you can't put it down until you finished it. Baron-Cohen writes well and his main points in The Science of Evil are these:One, we should not settle with the term 'evil'. Question it! Hitler was evil - sure thing. But don't stop there - what does this mean? Was little Adolf born with the evil gene and hence condemned to a life bringing nothing but death to the world? Baron-Cohen doesn't give a simple answer, but encourages us to think. And two, empathy is one of the most valuable human resources. Put beautifully in the very final words on the last page:"I hope you have been persuaded that this resource is a better way to resolve problems than the alternatives (such as guns, laws, or religion). And unlike the arms industry, which costs trillions of dollars to maintain, or the prison industry and legal system, which cost millions of dollars to keep oiled, empathy is free. And unlike religion, empathy cannot by definition oppress anyone."Finally, the book gets a few bonus points for including a fun Empathy Quotient (EQ) test in Appendix 1.

I was expecting a more thorough, in depth presentation into the scientific research done on the subject. Instead I read a short book, which had as its main purpose arguing the idea that empathy is one (if not the) of the most precious resources we have available. I do agree with this argument, but I do not think that the book managed to achieve its goal. I found it a bit reductionist and lacking, overall. But I will give it points for trying to put forward a very good point and for having noble intentions at heart. Also, because it gave me the concept of empathy erosion as a replacement for 'evil'.

The title of the book is misleading as the book is not at all about evil. It is in fact saying that evil does not exist, but what does is a lack of Empathy. The book goes on to describe different mental health disorders that do show a lack of empathy, being borderline personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, psychopathy, autism and asperger's. He then discusses the neuroscience and brain anatomy related to empathy. I found the book very interesting..it wasn't what I expected but it was enlightening. I recommend this book for anyone interested in psychology or social behaviors.

nothing substantial other than an almost common sense in the contemplated world, empathy. it is considered to be the key to almost every problem if you have it. the book doesn't tell you how to obtain more empathy nor how to deal with a situation in which little empathy flows among the stakeholders. The book uses some brain scans as proof without a much deeper understanding of how it happens. oh, it has some speculations and more than a few 'reasonable' predictions. It discovers little about the nature of the evil except for one more guess and a book to indulge himself in the idea and be satisfied with it.

This book was a much easier read that I thought. There was a chapter about the neuroanatomical associations with lack of empathy (leading to psychopathy), which I found fascinating but someone with less medical training might find tedious. I thought the author gave a good overview of different things that cause limits in empathy, and is there a point at which one can be classified as "evil." The fact that this book was written by Sacha Baron-Cohen's first cousin was also very weird. You wouldn't think Borat's cousin was such a preeminent scholar.

This book was very interesting in the beginning, but it got EXTREMELY repetitive very quickly. The same exact things were repeated over and over and over and over and over and over and over and it never even came to a conclusion.Also, as someone who has borderline personality disorder, and having met a lot of other people with the same disorder, (people who have this are described in the book as people with zero-negative empathy), I feel like Simon Baron-Cohen missed the mark quite a lot. I found a lot of the claims he made about BPD to simply be untrue and, frankly, a bit insulting.

Simon Baron-Cohen's work, and this book particularly, has had a massive effect on our understanding of the human psyche and of human behavior, and these effects will ripple out through time, helping us better come to grips with ourselves. While I have some quibbles with his assertion that empathy is always good, and more empathy is always better, this book is very much worth reading. In fact, I would suggest that for those who seek to better understand human nature this book is required reading.

A solid, relatively short book that makes the case for reading empathy with the significance I think it deserves. This book is probably most suited to those already having an interest in empathy, but its potential audience deserves to be much wider.Constructing a case for a potential expansion of the diagnostic criteria for what many of us see as disorders, such as narcissism, border line and psychopathy traits, Baron-Cohen writes in a generous tone that invites you as the reader to consider the wider applications of empathy.

3.5Very Interesting book about why it's so important that we teach empathy more, and how people can do the horrible things you see on the news. What started out as an intriguing promise for discussing empathy psychologically turned into an argument about understanding autism and a pretty narrow-minded view of psychopaths and how the court system handles psychiatry.I'm not an expert on these topics, but I did do an experiment in college using the Empathy Quotient so I was intrigued by this book. He mentions treating humans as objects, but rarely correlates the examples with sociological factors (I kept reminding myself he's a psychologist, but it seems his understanding of his own research was weak at best).I was lost when he delved into the pathos arguments about autism and how autistic individuals can be awesome. How does this have to do with evil? He spent more time on borderline personality disorder and autism than he did on actually arguing that the lack of empathy directly correlates to violence (but sorry, he actually says it doesn't, so I'm really lost as to why he wrote this book to make an argument only then to undermine it himself).In the very last section, he finally starts trying to make a point. By then, he throws in that empathy is the most important thing we have, and that we need to have a DSM category for empathy erosion disorders. I might have been more convinced if the argument wasn't fully based in pathos and anecdotes. I get it, people with autism get a bad reputation and it's not their fault, but you can't convince me that someone who rapes a woman because he doesn't know better, and would likely do it again because he thinks he did no wrong, is someone we can have walking free in society.nI also thought his understanding of the criminal justice system was poor, as he is using a micro lens of view instead of the meso or even macro levels of how it operates. The temporary lack of empathy doesn't mean a woman should be let down easier for killing her children. She knew what she was doing and, while obviously a horrible act for stupid reasons, she carried it out with efficiency.Overall I was very disappointed in this book. He had poor editing (jumped from using he to she/he to they in one sentence) and needed to sit down and come up with a more precise argument. He kept referencing horrible acts but then failed to show me how, in the research cited, it actually meant anything. I also feel he doesn't understand psychopaths as well as he thinks, because while they are more inclined to commit crimes, they simply lack any empathy at all. They usually realize at a young age they don't feel the same emotions or empathize with others, and that isn't something they will learn. There are psychopaths who just end up using people but don't commit crimes, though it's not as broadly discussed.ETA: I'm also not a fan of how he cherry picked research and then failed to give me actual numbers on the research groups used to prove a point. Telling me Denmark did a study on boys and 4% that almost died at birth committed 18% of the crime means absolutely nothing to me. Was it a study of 50 boys? An entire generation? The country? His explanations for the empathy circuit were pretty void of detail as well, just telling me that they showed less activity in xyz parts of the brain at certain times. Less than what? I'm not sure if he "dumbed" it down for the masses or if he felt people would just absorb the numbers blindly.Honestly the best thing that came out of this book was discovering that someone used Phillip Zimbardos prison experiment to write a book, Ordinary Men, which I will follow up with for hopefully better reading. For those who don't know, it was an experiment where college students were brought into a mock prison setting and divided into prisoners and guards. The extreme changes in behavior happened so fast that full blown riots were breaking out within the first two weeks. Zimbardo and his team had to shut the experiment down because it got out of hand so fast. Now why was this mentioned so quickly and not used in an argument about empathy and cruelty? I have no clue. Like all seeking book lovers, I began this book with the title, which made me pull it off the shelf. It took me a few minutes to realize this was that Simon Baron-Cohen, major contributor to the science of autism. His previous books, The Essential Difference and Mindblindness, wouldn’t appear to prepare his audience for a topic this grim. But they do, in fact, lay vital groundwork. Baron-Cohen has been working towards this book his whole life. I do see the tile as a headline, written for attention, because while the author acknowledges evil, he prefers the “cruelty” they’ve kept to the small print. His word choice is deliberate; we might hesitate to call ourselves evil, but we know ourselves well equip to be cruel. And it is quickly apparent that while he’ll talk about the extremes, the narcissists and borderliners and hyped psychopaths, his real concern is how everyday people lose empathy, because it is everyday people who have written human history. Describing a childhood of stories, human beings beings turned into lampshades, the neighbour who’d had her hands reattached backwards by Nazi scientists, there’s a cry of horror, yes, but his response was to begin to search empathy’s parameters. Most of the book is spent exploring the empathy scale his research group assembled, with human examples and discussion along the way. The first stop, our monsters, the zero-negatives, people capable of recognizing another’s emotion, but unable to emotionally connect with it. I appreciated Baron-Cohen's compassion for those we call outright evil, his recognition of their loneliness and frustration, as they are left on the outside, and must fill their lives with things that human beings are not built to thrive upon. Empathy is not a cuddly hippy feeling, but a mechanism for survival. The zero-negatives are briefly contrasted with the zero-positives on the autistic spectrum, those who may not be able to recognize emotion, but tend to possess deep affective empathy. He illustrated how, when autistics know someone is hurting, they connect closely and respond with compassion. One priority here, to make it obvious the autistic among us are, if anything, less likely to harm others, took on weight in the wake of the Sandy-Hook tragedy, and the resulting media squawk around mental illness that took an ugly turn against reason. From those who have not, we take a look at the majority who have. And we’re not too pretty in our possession. We let it go, lose it, are damn careless about the whole thing. Baron-Cohen contends that there's a reason empathy fluctuates, because to be locked in the empathetic extreme, feeling what others feel all day, we would be unable to function, complete tasks, or discover our own thoughts and feelings. He rotates the concept of healthy empathy, whether anyone can, in fact, be healthy and be at ten on the scale, possess “Super-Empathy”. He wraps science around a remarkable monk with seemingly limitless cognitive empathy, and a moving account of Archbishop Desmond Tutu, an example of his own ideal. And then we come to our darkness, the things that we do because we are only following orders, are walking through our everyday with blinders, are lost in depression and fury, are not paying attention to the human at the other end of our fingertips. Beyond the specificity of his research, what made this book different from other texts on the subject was the author. Baron-Cohen is a story-teller in the best human tradition, and I appreciated the conversation he opened as he went. He acknowledges the limitations of his science, and our ability to actually understand how another person feels, how they act outside the lab and observation. But what struck me most didn’t come till the close. He explains that empathy is a resource, one that we, our governments, communities, and parents, have assumed will be there when required, but historically have never understood. He underlines that empathy is teachable, there are signs and remedies when it erodes, and we must begin cultivating it. He argues for this being the most cost effective solution to social issues, personal, national, international, beyond being the most humane and balanced. Two fathers stand up in a synagogue. Each shares how his son was killed by their people's ancient enemies. The Palestinian wishes everyone Shabbat Shalom. The Israeli bids them Saleem Aleikem. They met through a phone line set up to allow bereavement calls across the barbed wire, and now they travel to mosques and synagogues around the world, speaking, “Your pain is my pain,” this suffering must end. Empathy as our most valuable resource. A concept long past due.A version of this review also appears at http://boxesofpaper.com/2013/02/12/du...

These are always hard reviews to write. Why? I am not anywhere as close to as educated or intelligent as these people. I do my best, but I believe I really just suck up the outline and carry on.  The author just so happens to be a professor of Developmental Psychopathology in the Departments of Psychiatry and Experimental Psychology at the University of Cambridge in the United Kingdom. As well as the Director of the University's Autism Research Centre, as if he wasn’t busy enough with the other engagements. On top of those achievements he also has a host of rather famous family members. Simon has a son who is an independent film maker and a daughter who is a song writer. Also, two brothers who are award winning film directors. His cousins are a famous computer scientist, a composer, film producer, playwright, University of Washington professor, and of course the famous comedic actor Sacha Baron Cohen (Borat.) Simon also has over thirteen independent book authoring's in the field of psychiatry. Impressive really.  In any event, in this short book, The Science of Evil, Simon attempts to root out what in the human condition or physiology causes evil. He starts by taking a very broad generalization of the Nazi experiments on Jews during World War 2 and then attempts to explain it as a series of empathy failures cause by dysfunctional parts of the brain. As the book progresses, Simon gives you more information about which parts of the brain make up what he calls the 'Empathy Circuit' and gives real world clinical examples of people that suffer some shortage on the empathy scale which can be directly attributed to reduced or no activity in these portions of the brain. The clinical studies are interesting; actually the whole book is interesting but starts to drag at the end. The last heading particularly feels like more of a rant or diatribe than any sort of case study. Simon, at the wrap, states that he feels that the current DSM (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders) is currently wrong, more to the point that it needs to be revised. According to Simon, nearly every mental disorder can relate back to a failure in empathy and that this is in fact the one unifying thing about mental disorders. If we could, for instance, re-categorize anorexia using the empathy classifiers (as anorexia patients display many of the same signs of other mental illnesses when using the empathy grouping system) would actually do a lot of good for the patient (hearing disorder in relation to their sickness only embellishing the issue and does not help to solve it, whereas hearing that it might simply be a lack of activity in a certain portion of the brain removes the blame and hurt associated with the illness.) He starts to lose me in the diatribe at the end. Not that I can dismiss the arguments, but simply that I do not necessarily agree with some of his conclusions. For instance, while Simon is vehemently against the death penalty for anyone showing a lack of empathy in a killing (because they were in essence experiencing brain malfunction), I openly welcome it. Furthermore, when he goes to explain and tie together the conclusion about how the Nazi's could systematically (nearly) wipe an entire sect of people without a single empathetic person in the process I think he fails.  Basically he breaks it down to:Person 1: My job was to arrest the people on the list. That's all.Person 2: My job was to ensure that these people got on a train. That's all.Person 3: My job was to ensure that the people got off the train and through the door. That's all.Person 4: My job was to ensure that the people got into the room. That's all.Person 5: My job was to ensure that I pulled the lever once the people where in the room. That's all.Person 6: My job was to move and dispose of the recently deceased. That's all. This seems shallow and I can't condone the thought that these people didn't know what was going on. I think Simon's epithetical argument makes sense on a one off 'mental disorder' situation but not in a culture wide setting. It just felt like a cop-out to me. He also postulates that a lack of empathy is the reason the world is going to shit, and if only we could all possess more empathy the world would magically fix itself. I personally find the notion romantic and whimsical, but exactly that. Overall, I would suggest Jon Ronson's 'The Psychopath Test' before this and if they enjoyed that, would I than shoot them to this book. Perhaps that’s simply personal choice as a reader.

(Content warnings: ableism; discussions of murder, war, and the holocaust.)This is a tough book to review, because some parts of it were good and other parts of it left me kind of squinting at the book and saying "but is it though?"I enjoyed the notion of empathy being a spectrum, as opposed to a trait you either have or do not have, and which can be turned off or enhanced by situational factors, as well as the discussion of which brain regions are involved in emotion recognition and regulation, and the idea that empathy can be taught.My issue with this book, and with Baron-Cohen's work in general, is largely with his specific types of "zero empathy", in particular with his explanation of autistic people, or what Baron-Cohen calls Zero Positive. Positive because the systemizing abilities of these individuals have allowed them to contribute to human knowledge and culture - and this is where that "but is it though?" response comes in, because I have known many, many autistic people who do not resonate with the empathising-systemising model, for example who describe themselves as having "nornal" affective but impaired cognitive empathy, as struggling with executive function or information processing to a point where effective systemising becomes difficult (don't forget that autism and ADHD are comorbid!), or as primarily having a neurotype that affects sensory processing, with the social deficits being a side effect of that, rather than the other way around.Granted, there may be different "types" of what we currently know as autism, and Baron-Cohen does acknowledge this in passing, as well as that some genetic factors that influence autistic traits do not have an effect on empathy, but it is interesting to note that all of the examples he uses for autism are male, and with some degree of savant skill, as this does not represent the entire autistic population and, crucially, is the demographic most likely to fit the "zero positive, high systemizing" view of autism that he is arguing for, with nonverbal autistics, autistic women, autistic POC, LGBT autistics, and those diagnosed in adulthood being likely to report less typical experiences. Another "but is it, though?" moment comes in his categorization of BPD as "zero negative" alongside ASPD. But are borderlines really suffering from an innate lack of empathy as a core feature, or is it just that the emotional turmoil of being borderline makes it hard to have the mental space for it, and they may be highly empathetic when they actually feel safe. He also writes off the possibility that hyperempathy (or "super-empathy", in his words) could have negative aspects as something "some people" have suggested to him, and presents some wildly inaccurate speculation on what stimming is, which he admits is an assumption, despite the fact that accounts of what stimming actually is and why autistic (and other neurodivergent) people stim aren't exactly hard to come by.Basically, when Baron-Cohen is talking about the general population, situational empathy erosion, or brain structure, he is very eloquent and insightful. When talking about mentally Ill, disabled, or neurodivergent people, he comes across as arrogant, ableist, and unwilling to take into account lived experience that doesn't fit his views. (I also would have liked more discussion of how empathy erosion happens and the effects of ideology and the systematic dehumanization of certain groups - selective empathy so to speak - instead of it being an afterthought, but I guess that's a topic for a different book.)

Having previously listened to a radio interview with Simon Baron-Cohen on NPR, I was very interested in reading more about Cohen's reexamination of the criteria that we are using (via the DSM V) to assess personality disorders. The disorders specifically covered within this text hone in on those in which there is an absence of or low degrees of empathy: Antisocial PD, Narcissism, Asperger's Syndrome, Borderline PD, and Autism. Cohen takes the time to explain the different regions within the brain that are responsible for our ability to feel empathy. He goes on to further discuss how the personality disorders listed differ on their degrees of empathy.Cohen's primary suggestion is that mental health professionals begin their assessments by examining the levels of empathy from a patient above all other criteria. While I feel it is completely accurate to state that the majority of these disorders (where an absence of empathy is present) are a combination of both genetics (nature) and environment (nurture), Cohen suggests that we can treat the majority of these disorders by simply expressing more kindness...What I see the mental health community assume so often is that the largest majority of people with disorders like Borderline PD, Narcissism, and Antisocial PD, proactively seek out help. It seems overly simplistic to assume that demonstrating empathy toward an adult with a disorder like any of the 3 listed above, is going to help that adult in any way. Firstly, you would need to rule out that this adult possesses the ability to feel anything at all. A seized opportunity to express empathy with a "child" who is demonstrating "empathy absent" behavior is one thing but, keeping in mind that most behavior becomes increasingly salient with time, I feel that Cohen's suggestion is very shallow. An individual whose main objective is manipulating those around him to get what he wants, certainly isn't going to seek out professional help as this would defeat his whole purpose.Cohen suggests that by exposing an "empathy absent" person to long and continual empathy, he will develop this absent trait. If the empathy absent person does not possess the ability to feel (other than perhaps, his own sense of pain and reward), I feel that it is highly unlikely for emotions to begin to kick in. Many people who possess the traits found in the Antisocial, Narcissistic, and Borderline personality disorders "do" understand the emotions of others and will often use these emotions to take advantage of any given situation. This affects the reward pathways in these individuals and thus, makes sense for them to manipulate the feelings of others to gain the best rewards for themselves.So, does kindness really matter? Of course it does! I feel however, that the only way expressing kindness can really make a difference within those who are lacking empathy, is to pay the closest amount of attention to our youth. Young people with conduct disorder and adolescents who demonstrate manipulation of those around them for personal gain are possibly the best attempt for success with "Empathy Exposure" however, this is still not a guarantee for success. Just because we feel varying degrees of empathy toward those around us does not mean that the person next to you feels anything at all,...or ever will.

At first, I really wanted to give this book a chance. I will fully admit the title caught my attention as I love studying anything even slightly related to abnormal/criminal psychology. But I'm pretty disappointed in this author for a few reasons:1. His sentence structure is awful. He constantly uses simplistic form (i.e., "Jackie is 9 years old. She has a cat. Sometimes the cat makes her mad.") and is incredibly redundant. I cannot stress how much fluff there is in this book; it reminds me of the times I had been assigned a topic I wasn't interested in during 8th grade, but had to meet a goal amount of words, so I'd just paraphrase what I said over and over. 2. He's convinced there isn't a cure for Type P, B, and N personalities (Psychopath, Borderline, & Narcissist). I'm pretty sure this man has either never heard of psychotherapy or doesn't believe in its effectiveness. As an individual with Borderline Personality Disorder, I can definitely attest that it does help significantly. Although I'm not aware of the statistics in its aid with those diagnosed as Psycho/Sociopaths or Narcissists, I'm aware that it is a common form of treatment considered for them as well. 3. Now, I know I went into this knowing the title, but he insists that the aforementioned Types do not constitute evil - yet, he is CONSTANTLY reassuring the reader of it. Okay... we get it. They're not evil, even though you group them in the Zero-Negative side of empathy, while placing individuals with autistic disorders such as Asperger's on the Zero-Positive side. And if you haven't read this book, you can definitely infer what he claims by the negative/positive parts of empathy: bad and good. 4. He often begins statements with something along the lines of, "In my view..." This irks me immensely because he's making claims yet throwing his damn opinion in when he can't fill the blank or answer his own question. Your view means nothing if you've no testable hypothesis or theory, nor data, to back up what you "believe." Especially in psychology. Overall, I wouldn't pick up another book (if there are any) written by this man. I'm sure he meant well and there are good parts of the book that are, from what I've learned from therapists and doctors along with my own studies (yep, Psych major here), factual for now in the world of psychology. However, there's so much bias toward condemning his Types that I can't stomach much more of it. Honestly, it's not really offensive, but several of his claims have been broken repeatedly by case studies where individuals with these personality disorders have either overcome or gained new perspective in which they're able to manage them. I just think it adds to the ignorance of those who lack empathy due to mental illness. Even if we can get hurt by these people, and whether or not they're murderers or manipulators, they're still human and if we want to end unnecessary woe caused by them, we should be able to offer up the same amount of empathy this author claims they should have to be a whole human.

This is a good read on the nature of empathy and how the lack of empathy manifests itself in different ways. It presents a lot of good facts and various perspectives on how empathy or the lack therof operates. I found his breaking down the lack of empathy in narcissism, psychopath, and borderline personality (Type-N, Type-P, and Type-B, respectively) to be extremely information and helpful way to classify 'evil.' Furthermore, his explanation that empathy sometimes temporarily fades is helpful with dealing with more real world situations (as behavior is combined not just by traits, but by situations that may lead to the suppression of otherwise dominant traits, such as empathy in some people). Finally, Baron-Cohen draws on a great observation on the extreme Systematizing tendencies of people with autism, and explaining how that inhibits empathy, but for positive purposes.However, one major point of critique: The author places an extreme emphasis on empathy as a solution to the problems. In the end, he suggests it so much so that super-empathy would be a beneficial response.However, I would suggest that empathy is only part of the solution; empathy is a response to attempts to response and help those who are hurting or to prevent from hurting someone else. AS such, it is always seeking to reach towards an ideal of the other being in a happy, well-functioning state. However, the the nature of reality as such is that we can not always help, and sometimes we must pick winners and losers. For instance, if we witness a potential murder in progress, it would be counterproductive to empathize with the aggressor; to do so would prevent protecting the victim. There is a winner and a loser; and empathy inappropriately place allows the aggressor to be the 'winner.'This is the sort of drama that plays out in the legal world (although with actually committed crimes), where rules have a greater prominence that just empathy. It is the rules about how to determine an oppressor and a victim that regulates empathic feelings towards persons, as sort of a 'codified' expression of cultural sympathies and empathies that tells individuals who to empathize with (a fusion of justice and empathy, two initially divergent strands in Western theorizing on morality). Unlimited empathy constantly runs up against the reality of a limited good. However, Baron-Cohen argues fora different direction with showing greater empathy towards perpetrators and against the death penalty. Perhaps Baron-Cohen is correct in that regards, but seems to show an unbridled expectations on the value of empathy.All-in-all a very good read and very scientific (although, the theory as presented is oversimplified). However, keep in mind his expectations on the value of increasing empathy is not as scientific.

This was a rather disappointing book about the psychology of "evil", or as the author re-defines it, "lack of empathy". In changing the label, he is trying to remove the religious connotations that surround human cruelty and talk about it in a more scientific way. This is a good start. He discusses how parental affection for children actually alters the physical structure of the brain, and changes the areas that seem to be most active when both children and adults express empathy. So his thesis continues well. He has some good case studies to illustrate various personality types. Unfortunately, after this, this slim volume (186 pages of text before appendices and references) tries too hard and doesn't really deliver the goods. When talking about his subject, the author too often uses mechanical terms like "empathy circuit" as if the people he is talking about are computers rather than human. He fobs off the most important parts of empathy onto the physical brain and genetics; clearly this is important, but while he acknowledges the effects of environment on the individual, fails to remind us the that brain structures change over the course of the entire human life, and decides quite early on that those with underdeveloped "empathy circuits" will never gain the ability to fully express empathy like "normal" people - but then goes on to say that people who have been imprisoned after heinous crimes should be released and given a chance to demonstrate what little empathy they have, while forgetting that, according to his argument, their lack of empathy and underdeveloped brains are what caused their crimes in the first place. He seems to be contradicting himself.He pays lip service to the idea that the experience of a lot of cruelty can harden people so they appear to lack empathy, but does not offer a solution on how to restore it. or even that it might be possible. He keeps referring to the Nazis of the Second World War as if they are the only bad guys in history, and neglects both worse and more modern instances of human cruelty, referring to them only vaguely in passing, if at all. He also fails to acknowledge wider systems that openly encourage a lack of empathy in the socializing of people in society at large, and why people who could easily show kindness and understanding tend to conform to unempathic systems rather than resist them. At the end, he becomes warm and fuzzy and recommends empathy as a panacaea, but no practical way in which to harness it - a very unscientific ending to what is supposed to be a scientific book.I would expect much more from a professor of psychology at the University of Cambridge. Stanford professor Philip Zimbardo explains the same thing much better and openly admits that we all have the capacity for evil - given the right circumstances, ordinary people like you or me can also be very, very nasty.

The title is very clickbaity. The book doesn't really talk about evil at all. Instead it focuses on different reasons why people lack empathy and the resulting negative (and sometime positive) effects. It was interesting, but not life changing.
