What makes human beings cruel? A big question attached to a little word, one Simon Baron-Cohen answers with aplomb in this brief but brilliant book.He suggests that instead of reverting to tired ideas about ‘evil’ we consider instead the possibility that those who commit the most unspeakable acts might have an empathy deficit. They lack the important though too often overlooked ability to put themselves in the shoes of someone else.He marshals a powerful argument linking progressive levels of lacking empathy personality disorders, narcissism and at the most extreme end of the spectrum psychopathy. In the process he draws on examples ranging from the Holocaust to countless ‘ordinary’ lives derailed by an inability to understand the feelings of others.In doing so he writes with compassion and clarity about people, some of whom might be tagged as monsters, showing them to be human, all too human.Baron-Cohen’s explanations are models of clarity, no mean feat when you consider that much writing about the brain and its operations tends to rapidly turn into a confusing alphabet soup of acronyms. This is something of a barrier to understanding to engaging with a subject that is fundamental to understanding who we are and why we behave the way we do.He also explores how lacking empathy might bring benefits, in areas such as mathematical reasoning and creativity. Although it is possible for brilliance to have its origins in dysfunction, the price paid by the individual is often painfully high.The message of this book is that explaining cruelty is more complex than just saying some people are born bad. They're born different certainly; but not all that much different from the rest of us.For its clarity, compassion and the sheer joy in sharing knowledge on display Zero Degrees of Empathy deserves to become a classic popular science text.

Though at times a very technical and scientific read, this is nonetheless a very crucial book. I debated between giving it 2 1/2 - 3 stars, but I think it warrants the latter because of what Simon Baron-Cohen hopes to achieve through writing it. Though it is scientific (and, to be fair, that is in the name of the book), Baron-Cohen does an excellent job of breaking down exactly what it means to be empathetic. Having just read "The Sociopath Next Door," I felt that this book makes a great companion piece if one is able to read them back to back. Baron-Cohen breaks down a lack of empathy into two categories : Zero-Negative and Zero-Positive. The first category contains Psychopaths, Borderlines, and Narcissists. I would disagree about Borderlines, if only because at one point I had most of the symptoms myself, and I'm the most empathetic person I know. I did not gain much from this part of the book since I had just read about psychopaths in TSND, and I've always known the symptoms/attitudes of those with Borderline and Narcissistic personalities. The next chapter, Zero-Positive, is a bit more intriguing. My brother has Asperger's, and while I also know those symptoms all too well, it was interesting to learn how empathy registers in his brain. I found a lot in this book that helps me understand the way my brother is. For that alone the book deserves three stars.Baron-Cohen goes above and beyond to use the facts of science to illustrate his main point, which is that empathy is an incalculably important resource. It may seem obvious, but we see every day how the world (and our own country) is becoming more and more corrupt. Get a quick grip on this book and learn how to develop empathy (if you are lacking in it, that is).

Have you ever wondered how humans can be so evil? After listening to the news, after hearing about all the terrorism in the world and all the wicked things humans do to other humans, do you ever wonder “How can someone be so cruel? Don’t they have a heart or feelings?” The answers lie in this book. “The Science of Evil” is a well-written nonfiction book by Simon Baren-Cohen. It starts out with a question along the lines of “Why do people do evil things to other people?” It gives examples of human cruelty (some of which are hard to comprehend) in the beginning. As you read these examples, the author leaves little hints leading up to his theory. He claims that the word “evil” can also be described as “empathy erosion”. As I continued to read, I noticed the trend of empathy. The author claims (and I agree) that the reason some humans are unpleasant to others is because they lack empathy. Simon Baren-Cohen does a good job of keeping his opinions out of his reasoning and explanations. He tells the reader that there are levels of empathy (or lack of empathy), and people can have varying amounts of it. For example, a murderer would have an extremely lower empathy level than, let’s say, a bully at school would. However, what they have in common is that both lack empathy. Simon Baren-Cohen doesn’t just explain why people can be cruel, he also explains what is chemically occurring in their brain to make them act that way. He tells us (and shows us with diagrams of the human brain) how the size of certain parts of the brain affects a person’s empathy level. Although the book’s topic is not a happy one, I enjoyed reading “The Science of Evil”, as it answered my questions on how and why human treat others as they do.

This book could have been a whole lot more, but it left me disappointed. What drew me to it - and made me excited about the first couple of chapters - was the premise that the word "evil" leads to oversimplification and deters us from approaching morally reprehensible (or at least questionable) behaviour in a constructive manner. I also looked forward to an in-depth discussion on the phenomenon of erosion of empathy, which I find to be particularly relevant to present-day reality.The neurological and genetic research was interesting, and as a layperson I really appreciated the introduction to the brain and to different methods of doing genetic research. Breaking down empathy to components was also an excellent idea. However, I found the "case studies" of subjects with borderline personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, Aspergers, etc. to be little more than caricatures. Those who know me also know how passionate I am about stigmatizing personality disorders, in particular BPD. I feel that someone who doesn't know much about borderline or only has a vague idea of it from hearsay and Hollywood movies would be very temped to take Baron-Cohen's "case study" of the manipulative mother at face value. The gratuitous use of the word "psychopath" also irked me a great deal. There are so many interpretations of it in psychology and (pop) culture, that I find it almost meaningless. There is a good reason why neither the DSM, nor the ICD actually use this term.While I found the author's interpretation of the causing factors for in-born low empathy very nuanced (just what I would expect from a good scientist), I feel the point could probably have been made in a more succinct way. More should have been devoted on the implications for society.

Never judge a book by its titleAfter finishing The Science of Evil, I found it misnamed and a little underwhelming -- Musings on Empathy by a Scientist would more apt. The science felt light, which is odd because the author is clearly knowledgeable and credentialed, and the underlying arguments seemed fairly straightforward and commonsensical: too much or, notably, too little empathy can be bad. A variety of studies showed that parts of the brain light up — or, in some cases, don’t light up — when empathy is in the house and there was a discussion of the “empathy circuit,” an imaginary coil of activity that basically involves the entire brain. There was also some description of various neurologic conditions and a broad and somewhat arbitrary classification system for empathy capturing the bell curve of distribution that seems applicable to almost any topic. The writing was solid, but the presence of the author and his opinions ever present, so this felt like more of a long op-ed with a few data points, or an intro class lecture, rather than science writing. For someone of his stature to arrive at “the world would be better with more empathy in it,” made for a lackluster journey. I’m glad I read it, but I wish it had been twice as long and much deeper. To be fair, if I’d read this book before Cruelty: Human Evil and the Human Brain, I probably would have given it four stars, but I still would have suggested a title change.

The overly-sensationalist title … The Science of Evil belies a considerably more mundane summary of studies designed to measure an individual’s empathy. Empathy is, of course, the ability to share or recognize emotions experienced by another creature. The idea being that a lack of empathy is a necessary (though not sufficient) condition of a person whose behavior we’d characterize as evil (treating sentient beings as if they were objects). Lack of empathy is one of the traits exhibited by psychopaths, but other personality disorders are also marked by low levels of empathy including: borderline personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, bi-polar disorder, insecure attachment disorder and others. Baron-Cohen describes the traits of each personality type in turn, using the behaviors of actual individuals to illustrate each problem. Simon Baron-Cohen a Professor of Developmental Psychopathology at the University of Cambridge.Unfortunately I found the book to be pretty dry stuff (especially considering that Simon is the cousin of Sacha Baron-Cohen aka: Borat … isn’t a sense of humor hereditable?). Baron-Cohen studies autism, a disorder that is also characterized by a lack of empathy, so the subject is right in his wheelhouse. While the content is fine, I think Baron-Cohen misses the mark when it comes to gearing the material to match his target audience (a problem many scientists turned writers appear to suffer from). In this case, I’d say the book was a complete success if the goal was to produce a text book for sophomore psychology majors. Not so much if his intended audience was the general public.

Summary: People only do 'evil' things because they lack empathy, and therefore view humans as objects. Lack of empathy (temporary or not) is a disorder. Clinical/scientific analysis of empathy and systemising circuits was a bit dull. Interesting parallels drawn between Zero-Negative (borderlines, psychopaths, narcissists) and Zero-Positive (autism & aspergers) disorders. New thought process when thinking about corporal punishment, see quote below (pg 119):“If we treat another person as essentially bad, we dehumanise him or her. If we take the view that every human being has some good in them, even if it is only 0.1 per cent of their make-up, then by focusing on their good part, we humanise them. By acknowledging and attending to and rewarding their good part, we allow it to grow, like a small flower in a desert.I found it a provocative idea because the implication of this attitude is that no one - however evil we paint them to be - should be treated as 100 per cent bad, or as beyond responding to a humane approach. The question is whether one can push this to a logical conclusion: if unambiguously ‘evil’ individuals (a candidate for this category might be Hitler) felt remorse for their crimes, and had been punished, would we try to focus on their good qualities, with a view to rehabilitating them? My own view is that we should do this - no matter how bad their crime. It is the only way we can establish that we are showing empathy to the perpetrator, not just repeating the crime of turning the perpetrator into an object, and thus dehumanising them. To do that renders us no better than the person we punish.”

This book has been on my shelf a while, but events of January 2017 caused me to pick it up, My main goal was a more nuanced understanding of empathy and of the psychology of non-empathy. In this, the book succeeded. In looking at individual without empathy, the author splits them into two groups: Zero-Negative and Zero-Positive, the "zero" being a 0 on a 0 to 6 scale of level of empathy (most of us are 3s or 4s). Zero-Negative include the borderline, the psychopath, and (most timely) the narcissist. Zero-Positive includes those with autism or Asperger's, for whom lack of empathy is a fact of life, but is not destructive (and in many cases, can be constructive). The author leads us through examples and general discussions on each of these types, along with discussions of the role of environment and genetics in the development of empathy.Compared to other popular psychology books I have read, I thought there was a bit too much of the "I think that..." without evidence for my comfort, and some base assumptions about individual psychology that were taken without question. One example, if you are familiar with the "trolley problem," is that because most people would not sacrifice one person to save five (because of empathy with the one), that to not feel that way is unempathetic. This seems to say that "normal" means that one succumbs to cognitive biases that are flawed but human. I'm more hopeful that we can learn to go beyond just taking our biases as-is. Overall though, a reasonable read on the topic.

I am no scientist but I found this a very accessible book on the complex and interesting subject regarding what is a very key aspect of human personality. My feeling is that this author wants to reach anybody who is dismayed and confused about news reports on the rise of autism and what appears to be a frightening increase of anti social behavior. I really like how the author proposes the importance of empathy as a basis to further research and and clarify the current definitions of problem personalities. The author's explanation of how research into brain functioning areas/parts and DNA can be used to define patterns of what we call evil behavior is also interesting enough for me to look forward to reading more in depth reporting. There are some interesting evaluations given and guidelines for spotting problem behaviors which we all could be a bit mindful of in ourselves and others. There are many examples given for what we call evil and good behavior.I found the examples of animals sharing food and caring for each other good points toward understanding and putting focus on empathy as an important survival strategy. The only example that I disagreed strongly on was the example of an evaluation of a Buddhist monk's empathy level which sounded like a possible condemnation of meditation as a blunting of empathy. Over all I found the book a nice opening for discussion of subject sorely lacking in today's political climate.

I totally agree with the premise of this book, that 'evil' is an unhelpful term in many ways and that we need to think about brain conditions that affect the ability to empathise. Having said that, I found it a slightly disappointing read. Most things are said over and over again, in different ways... even in the same paragraph sometimes. There's not much meat in it. The first part of the book did provide a breakdown of different brain conditions that could make it impossible for a person to empathise, and there were occasional little gems all the way through that were interesting. I just felt it could all have been written in a couple of good magazine articles.I was interested by the quiz in the back, which allowed you to assess your own ability to empathise. Again I felt it was slightly crude. I came out with a really high score (which is apparently very unusual... so that explains a lot to me!) One of the three questions I did lose marks on was: 'I really enjoy caring for people'. I wanted to say, 'Not true. But I do want to heal people through my writing.' I can't actually see why wanting to heal people through writing is less important... and some people with similar levels of empathy, (but need for intellectual stimulation) might become doctors, and I am sure there are other ways to express your care for people which I haven't thought of. So yes... all rather crude, but certainly a step in the right direction, as the subject is so very important.

This was a good book. Unlike some others I've read recently where authors basically write a mishmash of their observations/case studies, chaptered by subject, this book had a unifying theme/thesis. Simon Baron-Cohen had a goal of explaining the origins of evil. He argues that what we usually call "evil" in rather a blanket fashion can actually be defined more accurately, and more usefully, as a deficit of empathy. Then he goes on to explain all the different ways that people can come about having a deficit of empathy, implications for possible rehabilitation, implications for our greater society, etc.The actual book is much more interesting than I am making it sound, though. While I was already familiar with a great percentage of the neuroscience/psychology information that he presented, he used it skillfully to explain and illustrate his beliefs. What I most enjoyed, however, is that (again, unlike some other popular science books that I have read recently) the case studies he used were also carefully chosen to illustrate his points - he just didn't include a description of every narcissist/psychopath/ASD person that he had met in his career. Eminently readable and enjoyable. I even enjoyed that it was quite short - I'd now like to read a more extended, in-depth version, though, or a rebuttal, if someone has written one, as he didn't really go into any viewpoints other than his own.

Why are people cruel to each other? This book is about the search for an answer, a fascinating pop-science take on the latest research into empathy. Baron-Cohen and his colleagues have been researching how empathy is created by the co-ordination of several areas in our brains, and how that system is affected by genetics, life experiences and damage via injury or strokes. He's written previously about people on the autism spectrum whose empathy system works in a non-standard way. He's interested in how they might be helped to comprehend empathy in a way that works for them, which seems to have promising avenues of research ahead. I'd like to follow up on his writing on this topic.But most of this book is about people with what he calls empathy disorders, such as psychopathy, narcissism and borderline personality disorder. He feels that a scientific explanation is more useful than simply labelling them 'evil' or 'mad'. It opens up avenues for prevention and cure, by repairing the empathy circuit or improved knowledge of the environmental factors which create healthy levels of empathy.Mostly what I liked is that Baron-Cohen is very clear about the line between what's currently known about empathy and what's still speculation requiring further research. He's convinced me that it's the kind of problem that could lead to a happier world if we could crack it open and understand it better.

The author happens to be the cousin of Sasha Baron-Cohen (as in BORAT). That notwithstanding, the book presents a pretty unshrinking and unhumorous look at the lack of empathy which allows people to be able to see others as objects, to commit atrocious cruelties upon them, and to feel no remorse. He provides some historic, collective examples of genocide and systematic torture; then he switches to discussing the individual, tracing out the Psychopath, Borderline, Narcissist, and Zero-negative (less common; think Asperger's) types in terms of behavioral, environmental and genetic causes. His goal in writing the book is to suggest the need for a change in the DSM-V, to identify a new category called "Empathy Disorders." He makes a compelling case ... I for one believe we do need more discussion about empathy both in everyday life (as opposed to the shame and blame that have the potential to make us shrivel inside) and in extreme circumstances. Interestingly, though, he brings up how empathy depends upon the ability to keep our own consciousness as well as that of another (akin to two spotlights) in our mind simultaneously; but he never mentions Jessica Benjamin, the profoundly insightful psychoanalyst who wrote about this ability--what she calls "interdependence"--in her book BONDS OF LOVE, decades ago. I was surprised he didn't know it or reference it; seems a very odd oversight.

Baron-Cohen wants to replace 'evil' as an explanation for how and why people do terrible things with "empathy erosion". He argues that cruelty become possible when a person turns other people into objects. (Which Baron-Cohen freely admits isn't an idea new to him.)Baron-Cohen defines empathy as "our ability to identify what someone else is thinking or feeling and to respond to their thoughts and feelings with an appropriate emotion." suggesting there are at least two stages in empathy: recognition and response. (p 16) Baron-Cohen defines both psychopath and someone with autism as lacking in empathy. The difference being that the "psychopath is aware that he is hurting someone because the 'cognitive' (recognition) element of empathy is (largely) intact, even if the 'affective' element (the emotional response to someone else's feeling) is not. The person with classic (low-functioning) autism often lacks both of these components of empathy." (p. 120)I found Baron-Cohen's information and arguments interesting but not particularly novel. I have long personally defined evil as the lack of empathy, seeing people as objects rather than people.The prose itself and the way Baron-Cohen's ideas are presented are servicable but not particularly well-written. (Jared Diamond's books are much better written.)

Very thought provoking! When reading this you have to keep in mind that the definition of empathy is not that complex but not a narrow one. You need to see the that a single word (empathy) might be an umbrella term for a number of different component processes. In that respect, it is not much different to other psychological terms. For example, the term ‘language’ covers a number of different sub-systems (syntax, semantics, pragmatics, lexicon) as does the term ‘memory’ (long-term, short-term, episodic, semantic). With that being said, if someone's behaviour is the result of their low empathy, which itself stems from the underactivity of the brain's empathy circuit, and which ultimately is the result of their genetic make-up and/or their early experience, in what sense is the 'person' responsible?? These are complex medico-ethical issues. We obviously need to keep our socio-legal framework since it serves many valuable functions, including recognizing the victim or their family wanting to see justice done; but those with low empathy who end up in the criminal justice system also warrant our compassion, and may even warrant treatment within the health service. I have to admit this book left me with more questions and an unsettling feeling that our society isn't ready, or willing to look deeper and take into consideration this vision of 'empathy erosion'.

Having recently finished Steven Pinker's great book on the decline in balance, I wanted to go a little deeper into one of the topics that book covered - the role of empathy. The Science of Evil by Simon Baron-Cohen (Sacha's cousin; he briefly mentions him in the book) gives an enticing peek into the potential of neurological research into better understanding why people harm others. His hypothesis is that certain people lack empathy. Of these, some act in a socially negative way while others, most notably, those suffering from autism spectrum (especially Asperger's Syndrome) have brains that enable them to highly systemize information (i.e., pick up and work with patterns). These people are much inclined to follow rules and therefore aren't inclined to violence. He surveys the nascent research showing how different parts of the brain relate to empathetic behavior and what genes and hormones may play a role. There aren't any answers here, just a provocative glimpse into the future of psychiatry and the need for more focused research. His stated goal was to try to shift the conversation of the source of evil from the realm of religion and philosophy into the sphere of science. He makes a good start.

The Science of Evil was a book that I found mildly amusing as I read it. I found it amusing because it resounded the views I have carried and shared for years - all the problems of the world would go away only if one (thought with rationality and) acted with empathy.Baron-Cohen expresses the same with more scientific insights into the minds of the unempathic, classifying them into various personality disorders and the effect of neurological wiring of such people as seen by the acts carried out by them.What I liked about the book was that B-C distances the cruel acts from the theological concept of evil on the basis of science and scientific studies, forcing the readers to, at the least, think that individuals with low or zero degree of empathy are acting on the predisposition of their mental and neurological states.Even more fascinating was his ending query - doesn't reducing the perpetrator to an object and sentencing him/her to death make us unempathic like the victims of our judgements? While the question of punishing the violent offenders is more social and complex than the simplicity posed by B-C, it at least provides some food for thought on how one might look at others and dispense judgements.

The good parts> This book emphasizes the importance of empathy erosion in what we usually call antisocial behavior, trying to replace the umbrella concept of evil with one that is more amenable to scientific study. It also underlines the fact that, even though we may conceptualize personality disorders like BPD, NPD and AsPD as being Zero-Negatives from the empathy perspective, there are also Zero-Positives out there, namely autistic people who in spite of their complete lack of empathy can still have remarkable achievements due to their systemizing skills. The bad parts> The role of empathy as stated by Baron-Cohen seems to me exaggerated. Yes, empathy is important, but to regard it as a 'universal solvent' of problems and frustrations, I think it means to give it more credit than it is due. Also, the structure of the book seems at times very loose, even though the broadness of the topics adressed could be seen as a plus. Overall> It is an interesting book, the writing style is clear and concise, explaining all jargon terms and citing precisely the scientific literature. However, it could have been better. The theories it posits require of course further studying.

Hard to have many discussions with others about this book. I feel like all I talk about are morbid things between my thanatology (death & dying) textbook and this book which deals a lot with psychopaths. Not to mention the book on deck "wisdom of psychopaths." Needless to say, I'm a blast at parties right now.Anyway, the main points of this book had to do with evil being based on empathy. Does one objectify others to the point that they are ... objects? That's the makings of evil. However, he used the concepts of zero-negative and zero-positive empathy. Differentiating between a psychopath (no empathy and disregard for the ability of others to even feel) and the autistic (lack of understanding to see they feel but not wanting to hurt others). Each has the potential to hit a child, for instance, but only the psychopath has the intention ... or at least the ability to tell that they are hurting others and not caring.The author put this in evolutionary terms to show how we may be getting different individuals ranging in the empathy spectrum and it hasn't been weeded out. The autistic tend to be much more adept at pattern recognition, which is an important facet to intellect. Seems they are inversely related.

BRILLIANT. This is a fascinating read. I did have a bit of bother with all the references to the parts of the brain and what bit did what etc. The first chapter was also a tad harrowing. But this book really seized my imagination and truly blew me away. It investigates human cruelty and what drives, or allows it within the brain. Empathy, which is something that I used to just confuse with sympathy is a key player here. It is a fairly simple concept, but amazingly insightful. If we don't care about the person or their feelings, why would we give a shit if we upset or hurt them. Baron-Cohen looks at the parts of the brain and the chemical goings on that could cause one person to care deeply about their actions and another person who shows no response of what they inflict or a lack of consideration before acting in a cruel or hurtful manner. Experiments (all legal and non nasty)show how different brain activity appears to mould different personalites. I can't recommend this highly enough. Thanks to JJ Marsh for loaning me the book. Careful mind, it will have you judging all your friends and colleagues.

great subject matter...the actuality of spirituality. Describing the theology of ' oneness ', the essence of presence, in scientific terms...that's got to be relevant. He doesn't claim to know anything, doesn't make egocentric claims as a reductionist...very cool, especially where psychiatric matters are concerned. He's noticed tendencies and sliding scales along spectrums, sliding scales that inter-relate. Has a delicacy with his astute observation - doesn't close it off as fact. ...i think that's key to contemp science - a butterfly poised on the slider of a layer of the mixing desk, ambient trance can always be manipulated to become the most savage of hard beat...he's asking the right questions from a reasoned perspective...doesn't quite explore epigenetics sliding in to original theology but who has ? He hasn't closed any doors and hasn't waltzed off skipping through a meadow of purple scented flowers - he's added to my thinking although i have yet to know anything....my puzzlement is yet more intriguing, i suspect myself of idiocy with an aspiration to a recognisable disorder of person...

This is more of a study of empathy and a review of the various scientific studies that show either in the brain or genetically how different levels of empathy correlate with the different personality disorders that are often associated with "evil" (i.e., psychopath). There was a fair amount of information about autism and Asperger syndrome that I felt was out of place in context of the title (but would be completely in place in a book on empathy). I also felt that the author's conclusions that rehabilitation can work for those with some of these serious disorders wasn't very well substantiated or supported. I'm not convinced that you can change some of these people who have the zero-empathy/personality disorders that cause them to be inhumane or cruel. There is no motivation for them to want to change their behavior, so I don't see how just treating them "nicely" is going to work. There was a quote from his cousin, Sasha Baron-Cohen, that seemed to be included as a plug for a famous relative rather than support of the material. It was true enough, but... just felt off in context for me.In short, some interesting material but fell short of expectation.

I was initially really intrigued by this book (it's this month's selection for my cognitive science book club), and I've read a bunch of neurology, but sadly this one really fell short of my hopes for it. I've read the studies that it references tying borderline to early childhood abuse, but I think he's just wrong in his attempts to construct a similar narrative for psychopathy. (I'm not a professional neuroscientist, but my layperson's reading of the literature doesn't seem to support his construction there.) And his overarching thesis just kind of fell apart at that point for me. I'm not sure you're going to get a deep treatment of the autism spectrum as sort of a couple chapters side note in a book on empathy, but I felt he really didn't do justice to the connection he was attempting to make there. I do agree that there's interesting findings in how ordinary people bring themselves to dehumanize others and be terrible, and that genetics and environment both have roles, but that's such a set of bland statements that nearly everyone is going to agree with that. Zimbardo's "The Lucifer Effect" was more thorough, if more disturbing.

Great book. This book changes your prospective on what we consider evil. In this book the Author gives you an understanding on how and why people act so vicious and cruel to others. After reading this book you judge and think differently about people who kill and harm others. He speak about the many mental disorders people have and how their mental disability effect their everyday life and how they respond to other people. You finally see how and why Serial Kills and other murderers do the things they do. The common denominator is their mental disability and how different parts of their brains are not working properly or over- acting. Most of it stems from the part of the brain that activates ones Empathy. He really drives home the point people are not evil they are mental disabled. After reading this book you will no longer say someone is evil, you will then say or ask what is wrong with them. And have a certain feeling of sorry for them and for the victims. You being to understand a lot about people. You also understand the effects of ones up bringing, that in return has a lasting effect on your brain.

Super interesting topic that just caught my eye on the bookshelf and I had to buy it. Unfortunately, the ideas (which are great and I really want to get on board with) on the whole don't seem to be particularly well researched or developed. There's many occasions where he begins to explore an idea but stops midway with the excuse 'this is yet to be tested' or 'this is still a new topic'. If you're gonna write a book about it and try to pioneer a whole movement in psychology about it, make the effort to do the research yourself... So yeah, I don't know if I can wholly trust the conclusions the guy comes to, nor do I feel like it's answered the questions of why humans perform acts of cruelty.It's obvious his speciality is zero empathy within autistic minds, as this is the subject he seems much more comfortable writing about, and that feels much more grounded in evidence. It was interesting to read about autism and the systematic, pattern-solving mentality but that's not what I picked the book up for. Otherwise I'd read a book on autism. It's raised more questions than it's answered, which could be a good thing, so I'm on my way to find more reading material!

A very interesting book. Not sure about it being the Science of Evil, but it does give a very good account of empathy disorders, their causes and effects. There's some complaints here about the lighter tone but I actually appreciated that. It feels very much like a layman's introduction into an emerging and interesting field of study.I even learned a bit about myself. I don't believe I am autistic and would not try claiming this. However I have become more aware of autistic elements of my make up and behaviour. And is somewhat confirmed with my lower than average scoring in the empathy test. I think I was over playing to the book so my actual EQ is likely higher than calculated, but still significantly less than average. Which I found fascinating.Somehow reading this book as giving me some useful insight into what make me, well me. It'd be interesting to hear the authors thoughts on issues around low but non-Zero EQ and how that translates into the possibilities for criminal, disruptive or destructive behaviours. The shades of grey in the science of evil, if you will.

This is a surprisingly short look at some of the biological/psychological evidence that what people call "evil" (generally, cruelty toward others) is better defined as "lack of empathy" due to temporary or permanent interactivity in the "empathy circuit" in the brain (a group of about 10 regions in the brain associated with different aspects of empathy). The author uses the examples of borderline personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, psychopathy, and autism spectrum to illustrate extreme examples of impaired empathy (the author takes pains to emphasize that autism doesn't fall into the same category as the three personality disorders). The book is heavily annotated with references, but is fairly readable to the educated layman (keeping the regions of the brain straight was a challenge, though). It was enjoyable and interesting, but at the same time felt a bit short and shallow; I wanted more digging into the details (which, to be fair, may require the state of research to advance more). Also, something about the prose style felt a bit stilted to me. Worth a read of you are interested in the subject.

It was an interesting, easy-to-read exposition on what scientists think they know about why humans sometimes tend towards cruelty. The prose is extremely repetitive, which in some cases is needed, but in most it's a bit irritating. The book is already short enough, and I feel like there were some questions left unanswered. Basically the underlying message to take home from this book is that "evil" can be equated to a lack of empathy. The most adaptive and practical way to live is to have a moderate level of empathy (everything in moderation); too little empathy (the ability to care for others and put yourselves in their shoes so to speak) allows for guiltless (and sometimes ignorant) cruelty, but too much empathy allows a stressful existence in which the empathizer negates their own needs by caring too much for others. All in all this was an interesting and informative exploration of the darker side of humanity. The extensive reference section will provide anyone with more information, should they wish for it.

Simon Baron-Cohen's new book describes empathy and evil. Evil comes from empathy erosion and "turning people into objects." He gives graphic examples of this kind of evil throughout the book, from sadistic cruelty by soldiers in the Democratic Republic of Congo to the criminal in a supermarket line who robs a woman's ring, taking her finger with him.although i liked the descriptions of different levels of empathy.my only complaints about this book is he put empathy on a scale, and yet i dont even think i fit into any of this categories. hes also missing guidelines for developing empathySomething more fundamental is missing from this discussion of "the science of evil." The widespread cruelty throughout history by leaders and collective groupings of people points in the direction of deeper biological factors that override empathy. These, for example, may involve the role of alpha leaders and their followers, and tribal dynamics that result in the need to hate, demonize and dehumanize,and we cant forget enviromental factors..

What's new about the idea that a lack of empathy helps explain cruelty, or the idea that a combination of environmental and genetic factors determine the development of empathy? Nothing. Baron-Cohen's argument for reclassifying certain mental illnesses as empathy disorders is persuasive and his discussion of these illnesses and the associated environmental and genetic backgrounds make the book worth reading. In fact, if the book had stuck with this key idea, I'd have given it 5/5. Unfortunately, the philosophical discussion is sorely lacking. I'm not convinced that lack of empathy is a necessary condition for cruelty and as Baron-Cohen notes, it's never a sufficient explanation. A 'theory of human cruelty' ought to be more thorough. Baron-Cohen's discussion of the implications of his theory is also lacking: He merely states his opinions, rather than arguing for them. (At least he is intellectually honest in this.) A fascinating subject and an excellent first few chapters, but ultimately a bit disappointing.

This is a "scientific" study of evil. I found it somewhat interesting but it, for me, bogged down in the brain and hormone oriented explanations. It struck me it was sort of justifying that the performers or evil might not be responsible due to their level of empathy.With all the positive references to other researchers in the field I got the impression that maybe Baron-Cohen wants validation and acceptance of his theory of empathy re-inforced or validated. then I also got curious if he wanted these other folks in his "business" to maybe make his book required reading.I read this book as part of a course on "evil" an- this was the third of five books. The next deals with the Nazis as part of that book and this one, and the first two, include the German Hitler Nazis too. (I am not sure what is in the fifth book) - So I am wondering if, in the west, one can write or even use today a book on evil that does not include references to the Hitler Nazis?

I agree with Baron-Cohen that Hannah Arendt's analysis of Adolf Eichmann in terms of the "banality of evil" is not a good explanation of the Holocaust. "Evil" is a religious concept, which does not really explain cruelty at all. It makes much more sense to think about cruelty in terms of empathy disorders, which result from a combination of biological and environmental influences, which determine temporary or permanent underactivity of neural empathic circuits. The Holocaust is in this interpretation a result of a combination of small unempathic acts, not of small banal evil acts. The difference is crucial. No one - however evil we paint them to be - should be treated as 100 percent bad or as beyond responding to a humane approach. Showing empathy to the perpetrator, not just repeating the crime of turning the perpetrator into an object and thus dehumanizing them, should be a way to react to cruelty.

Intriguing treatise on the explanation of evil as a lack of empathy and its psychological and neurological roots in the brain. The author explores borderlines, psychopaths, and narcissists and both the biological (genetic) and environmental factors that cause people to develop such disorders. The author also presents into his own research on the subject of empathy, outlining the areas of the brain that have been found to play a significant part in the "empathy circuit" as he calls it. This book is definitely geared toward the scientifically inclined, as the parts on actual brain regions can be a little dry to an average reader, but the questions raised and argued are fascinating. Great read for those interested in psychology, neuroscience, or those curious about why humans are capable of cruelty.

I think he did an excellent job of describing his theory. I'm not entirely convinced that the theory is correct, but that's a whole other discussion. As the parent of a "zero-positive" child, I did have a problem with how simplistic his categories were ( although this is partially an inherent problem in categorization itself). I have to say, I didn't recognize my daughter (or even myself really) clearly in any category. However, I was very interested in some of the research in brain imaging that he covered.I also know a person who would hypothetically be included in the "zero-negative" category but she also didn't clearly fit in any of the three types under it.I guess I expected a more nuanced understanding of particularly the autistic/zero-positive category from one of the leading researchers of autism

A very interesting book. There is a lot of info about specific brain regions and whatnot, however, that got a little too scientific and technical for me. As a parent of a daughter with aspergers, however, I found the info interesting but a little too science minded v/s real world applicable to really connect with.....I think sometimes you just have to be there to get certain things:)...no offense intended. I think overall Simon Baron-Cohen is one of the best in this field of research, but I think until you actually parent a child with aspergers, it is impossible to really GET it. Good book overall though. I think there is always a tendency in academics to somewhat overthink things :) A little more believing their own eyes and a little less analyzing things to death would be my advice :) 4 Stars overall.

Extremely illuminating.Good science IMO.I don't really think the term "evil" is very useful or accurately descriptive anymore. It is a religious atavism IMO.The more descriptive scientific term would be empathy-deficiency.It's a "brain bug".Human brains are biological; they are a product of a combination of biological evolution and social “sculpting” (environmental influences).Natural selection works because of the vast variation that biology provides. The variety of human brain structure is vast beyond belief.The variety in human brains spans a huge spectrum, a bell curve from the most zero-empathy psychopathic through what we would call average or “normal” through the super-empathic.Attempting to reduce this vast spectrum of brain range to black/white, good/evil is oversimplifying to such a huge degree as to become almost meaningless scientifically.

Ugh. What else can I say about this book. This was not so much an informative novel about an interesting theory, but rather a giant pat on the back for the theory that proves empathy is real, and evil isn't. This is just a self congratulatory piece of work based on a thesis that, while potentially realistic, is still unproven. The book is peppered with grandiose pat-on-the-back references to former PhD students of the author, and refutations of the work of others based solely on his own opinion. I'm giving this more than two stars based on the fact that his theory is interesting, and it gave me some food for thought related to psychopathy and empathy, and how we could formulate therapies for them, But other than that, I found myself internally arguing with the author and disappointed with this book.

You know, it was an interesting book and not at all a chore to read, but I didn't really feel that the author began to get to the meat of the issue until we reached his parting reflections on evil at the end of the book.Indeed, the discussions about psychological conditions that cause a person to be bereft of empathy were fascinating and relevant, but I think the book could have been even better had the author further explored some of the situations when otherwise normal, good people experience empathy erosion, such as those he briefly discussed at the end of book like acts of terrorism, genocide or crimes of passion.Despite this, I did enjoy the book and if you're at all interested in psychology you'll probably find the book a good read given the in depth discussions on narcissism, psychopathy Borderline Personality Disorder and autism.

Oy! How did I not discern this book was a load of garbage from the free sample?! I was bamboozled by the interesting stories on human cruelty. I'd be embarrassed to be a mentioned colleague. Are these people even scientists? Maybe I could overlook the poor writing or the often used, not needed use of parentheses... I cannot overlook the long winded, needlessly repeated explanation on empathy. Only those with zero empathy need to read this book- which should be titled: Empathy For Dummies. This charming sentence finally made me call it quits: "Fortunately, not all people at Level 0 do cruel things to others since others at this level just find relationships very difficult but have no wish to harm others."

While I felt this book was informative and put a new perspective on how we should define "evil." The author is clearly an expert in his field and the book was well-researched. Being someone who enjoys non-fiction and learning about science, I was never good at science and prefer books that can break science theories and terms in layman's terms that I can comprehend. Baron-Cohen's book is heavily laid with academic and scientific terms and explanations that go way over my head, such as explaining in detail how different parts of the brain are related to empathy. Again, while the author certainly knows his stuff, the book was too detailed for me to do more than barely grasp the concepts explained in the book.

This book explores a scale of empathy which covers those who have a high degree of empathy to those who have zero empathy negative, like psychopaths, narcissists, and people who have borderline personality disorder. Plus those who have zero empathy positive and see the world through systems like people who have Autism Spectrum Disorder. Baron-Cohen explores extreme cruelty throughout history, such a the Nazi regime. He also discusses research studies that theorize how a child becomes evil or comes to posess a zero empathy negative personality. I found this book a fascinating read and it helped me understand why there are people out there that choose to do horrible things to other people; especially children. This book was a good read to wanting further understand bullying and autism.

An enjoyable and remarkably earnest exploration into the world of "Zero Negative" disorders (Borderline Personality Disorder, Psychopathy and Narcissistic Personality Disorder). Author Simon Baron-Cohen (cousin of Sasha, a.k.a. "Borat") argues convincingly that empathy, or lack thereof, lies at the nexus of all "evil" behavior. I'm won over by his earnestness, but I had a difficult time with the last chapter, which felt a bit too conversational and shallow to be a fitting end to a serious work of nonfiction. With that said, the last couple pages—in which the author describes two bereaved fathers, on Israeli and one Palestinian, who now campaign together to stop the violence—will stick with me for a while.A fun read, but still not a first-rate book.

I read this a few years ago because a guy I was dating bought a copy for me. He thought many people were psychopaths and identified them based on criteria from this book. Well, we didn't go out for very long because he was cray-cray. However, I enjoyed the book and appreciated that he gifted it to me, even though it was a little odd. If you are interested in the concept of empathy, and how one develops empathy, it naturally follows that you must also look at the opposite end of the spectrum. If you read the book, be prepared to be grateful that you weren't deprived and turned into a psychopath while you were a tiny and defenseless infant. And then be very depressed when you realize how easy it is to create significant trauma, and what is the world coming to?

Simon Baron-Cohen (Sacha Baron-Cohen's cousin) is a really bright guy who does a great job with quick explanations. The problems with this book, however, begin with the title. If it were called "on empathy," I think it would better summarize the work. There are a few mentions of "evil" things, but the best work is on the autism/Asperger's side of the zero empathy spectrum, where he talks about pattern-seeking. Even at 180 pages this book still felt too long, because S B-C used a lot of the setup stuff (more on that later; as we'll see in chapter 5; etc.) and a lot of review and repetition, in a book that can be read in under 3 hours.

A great book and a (relatively) easy read. I admire Baron-Cohen's determination to avoid easy definitions or categorizations. It is overly simplistic and even harmful to society to label people we don't understand as 'evil' and leave it at that--he argues not that we should rush to forgive those who commit terrible acts, but rather that we should try to understand how humans are capable of atrocities. He makes a compelling case for the role of damaged, underdeveloped, or temporarily lapsed empathic parts of the brain in committing evil acts. A great read for anyone interested in scientific inquiry into human nature.

An intriguing book by Baron-Cohen which describes his work in devising a theory of empathy (or the lack of it) and how to map the areas of the brain involved in empathetic thinking.The book was shorter than I expected, but wide ranging in its treatment of the subject matter. Hopefully the writer will return with a sequel at some point which gives an update on some types of the zero degrees of empathy which Baron-Cohen himself admits needs more research.As a writer, Baron-Cohen lacks the gifts of someone like Antonio Damasio, who also writes about neuroscience and related fields, but B-C's work is cutting edge stuff and therefore well worth the read.

The meaning of the book was good. I believe it is important for others to know the science behind evil. The main focus of this book was the empathy gene. The author had very good points and the first few chapters were very interesting, but as the book should have been shorter. I feel the author meant well, but dragged things on for too long. I really enjoyed the charts becasue that helped me visualize this. I also liked how the author talked a lot about autism and had some connection stories or application stories. Overall, this book was really good information wise, but towards the end I almost had to force myself to finish it.

This book will serve as a cornerstone in my studies of human cruelty. Baron-Cohen lays out a great argument for empathy as being one of our most valuable resources.He describes a state of Zero-Negative empathy as active exploitation of others (Psychopaths, Narcissists, Borderline Personality Disorder). He continues to argue that having zero empathy is not always bad as he elaborates on Zero-Positive empathy (Aspergers, autism spectrum) as those who have no Theory of Mind but do not intentionally hurt others. Some even benefit from the deficiency by having a skill in Systemizing, wherein they possess a super-focus and near-limitless memory for learning patterns.

A mediocre read at best, the author attempts to remove the stigma associated with the word "evil," and replace the concept with a more substantive ideological framework. The framework views "evil" as a lack of empathy, rather than an empty diatribe. In addressing this, the author covers 4 psychological conditions; narcissism, borderline personality, psychopaths, and autism. He juxtaposes the the cons of a lack of empathy (zero negative) and pros (zero positive), and explains how zero positives have benefited civilization. I recommend this read as a fun method of addressing such a controversial tag line- that being evil.

some of this was interesting, mainly when he moved into spheres of psychoanalysis. I especially liked the short discussion of bowlby's 'pot of gold' theory and the discussion of systematizing in people with autism. But for the most part it is too speculative, and too many findings you'd expect in a phd thesis rather than a popular book. Also at times felt more like a historical commentary on other work that has been done in this field rather than a new contribution to it. Also, whilst he clearly centralises the importance of psychoanalysis and constantly comes back to it, he never incorporates any psychoanalytic theory in his discussion which seems a major flaw

Interesting for its discussion on the current state of empathy research and the brain, but I found it frustrating in his unexamined assumptions about where "normal" levels of empathy should be defined. I also believe that while there are probably stable levels of empathy in personalities, cultural roles have often proven easily able to over-ride this circuit for otherwise normal people, i.e. the famous class where undergraduates were divided into "prison guards" and "prisoners," and abuses of power by the "guards" quickly spiraled out of control.

borat's brother (or uncle or something) develops an empathy quotient (EQ) quantification system. basic point is that certain categories of anti-social nihilistic lumpenproles, such as NSDAP true believers, stereotypical engineers, school shooters, insurance adjusters, and unaware recidivist jaywalkers, lack some biotruthy stuff that everyone else possesses in abundance. A representative quotation:Neuroscience number one exporter of neo-hobbesianism!Other sciences have inferior neo-hobbesianism!

Very interesting concepts and novel approaches to understanding certain psychiatric conditions, e.g. personality disorders (Borderline, Psychopathic, Narcissistic)or conditions like Asperger Syndrome, Autism, Anorexia in context to their lack of empathy. Various possible reasons are laid out for acts of cruelty and the general inability to experience empathy. An attempt is made to explain the difference between cognitive and affective empathy. The existence of morality or lack thereof in certain psychiatric conditions is also examined. Fascinating read.

this book explores human cruelty (evil) through the eyes of science (nature and nurture). i can't think of a more important topic for our times. if we can better understand our greatest weakness (the origins of violence), then there is hope for improving. in particular this book discusses: what is the relationship between cruelty and empathy (or lack of)? what parts of the brain are involved? how does environment influence/affect these matters? how do the cruelest and most violent people in our society get to be that way? this book will tell you! read it!

This book purported to be a new theory of human cruelty, and it did have some very interesting insights - does 'evil' derive from a lack of empathy, do all people fall somewhere on a bell-curve within this spectrum of empathy, and whether disorders such as Borderline, Psychopathic and Narcissistic Personality Disorders can be explained in terms of this?Alas I found myself pretty low down on the empathy spectrum, having performed the quiz within the book (typical man!). I will kill again :-)

Borderline personality disorder, psychopathy, narcissism, autism and Asperger Syndrome have one thing in common: lack of empathy. Baron-Cohen has spent his career defining and understanding what causes these five (and other) conditions. He is an award winning psychologist. He has discovered it all starts in the brain and the way it is wired. A malfunction of the wiring causes a lack of empathy or caring how other people feel. The brain is influenced by genetics, environment and social interactions with our primary care givers.

I didn't finish this book because it was too medically technical, and it requires study. HOWEVER, his basis for study was fascinating. Sometimes you glean just one thing from a book that helps formulate your thinking, and this book gave me new outlooks on empahy and evil. I learned so much on how he determined that evil is really a lack of empathy with LOTS of variations, and we're all on a bell curve. Some day I'll pick it up again. I'm giving it four stars just because light bulbs went off in my head!!!

Learned a lot. Not able to really critique central premise of the book, but from my uneducated point of view it seemed a little oversold. Still, the tour the author gives of empathy-related disorders is fascinating and although the case for a common chemistry that ties together everything from borderline personality disorder to NPD to autism is outside my ken, it was interesting to see the various ways that a lack of empathy can manifest, and to think about how big a role empathy plays in the social order.

Cohen's goal is to shift the debate about behavior from a discussion of good and evil to the much more complex issue of empathy. By redefining "evil" as a question of empathy, he attempts to create a space where we can more directly identify, prevent, and treat evil on an individual and cultural scale. Equal parts biological, psychological, and cultural, the book is a fascinating approach to conflict prevention and resolution, but he may be pushing it a bit too far. Still, he creating space for optimism in the face of darkness, and I applaud his efforts.

Some interesting connections in this book, primarily developing the idea that it is a lack of empathy that allows us to objectify others and therefore engage in purely selfish acts (or even acts of cruelty), that would be impossible were our empathy not diminished in some way. Baren-Cohen (not the comedian, but that Baron-Cohen's cousin), argues that the development of empathy comes from a combination of wiring in the brain and experience from our youth. There are some interesting case studies, as well.

A short but informative book exploring empathy, Cohen's theory being that cruelty is in fact a lack of empathy.He explores the neurological and environmental factors that can cause people to have little or no empathy. The main personality types associated this condition are psychopaths, narcissists, borderline personality and autism disorders. Cohen explains that those displaying no empathy are often lacking in particular neurological circuits , whilst abuse, neglect and other childhood factors can influence this behaviour. A fascinating and lucid read.

Read this book. Now. I give it 5 stars not because Baron-Cohen's writing is sublime (it's workmanlike) but because of the concise and clear manner in which he tackles his subject. This book alongside Lieberman's Social should be required reading for everyone. The glitzy title helps this book sell in America where Empathy is a decidedly "not macho" notion but Baron-Cohen explains the importance of empathy and how neuroscientists are trying to understand both it's absence and how to cultivate it. Read this book.

Starts strong and gets redundant pretty quickly. A lot of pseudoscience and leaping to conclusions (which seem to me to be probably correct but still require a more solid base of evidence to be put forward for the author to make such confident assertions as he does here).This reads more like a long form essay. There isn't enough new information here to fill a book so Baron Cohen waxes on and reiterates his arguments as infinitum. It's telling that the final chapter is put forward as a sort of "in summation" addendum and yet takes up 40 pages of a ~190 page book.

so surprised at the low ratings on this one- it is a bit too long, but gets 5 stars from me for the neat layout and basic premise that empathy and systemizing reside on bell curves that overlap. This resulted in a lightbulb moment for me and provided a helpful context in many cases.I haven't yet read Baron-Cohens other writing on autism, but it is an area of professional expertise for me and his take is worth my time as it presents things from a unique perspective. I would not call this pop-pyschology, but food for thought.

'Evil' people do not exist. 'Evil' actions arise where empathy is lacking or impaired. That's the essential premise. The author proves this by looking at different categories of people with 'zero-empathy' - narcissists, psychopaths etc. All the author's arguments are logical and pretty easy-to-understand but he often spent the longest time labouring over pretty uninteresting parts (in my opinion). I got the impression that he is someone who loves what he does and is clearly enthusiastic about his subject but failed to convey this to me.

I wished for more information, but there were several interesting ideas. It was highly focused on the brain's "empathy circuit". He discusses environmental and genetic associations with empathy disorders, and classifies different empathy disorders as "Zero Negative" and "Zero Positive". One of the most interesting new ideas I took from this book was that Anorexia and Asperger's Syndrome have several commonalities, and possibly Anorexia is a manifestation of Asperger's.

A disjointed, fluffed up mess that scratches the surface of empathy study but doesn't offer any real substantive findings nor a coherent point other than Baron-Cohen had promised to deliver the book some six years previously. Also out of place were his assertations that those on death row should be granted leniency once they express remorse--statements like that belonged in another book, not an allegedly scientific examination of human empathy.

Malcolm gladwell this guy ain't. He could have put most of the technical stuff in the footnotes and made this a much shorter and easier read. But he deserves credit for tackling a subject that needs to be addressed--as the world becomes more secular we need to address "evil" outside of the context of religion. Cohen does a creditable job of categorizing the types of Zero empathy. Hopefully future literature can build upon his framework.

I thought this book was interesting and presented some good options when thinking about "evil". It is written by a scientist, so be prepared to hear a lot about his personal research as well as the research of colleagues. I found the chapters about Zero-Negative and Zero-Positive to be most enjoyable. Bottom line is if you are interested in "evil", empathy, or the human condition I would suggest reading this book.

I am not a college graduate, however, have an interest in this subject matter and am well-read. Overall I liked this book and the ideas it presented. The chapter where he gives are the names and abbreviations of the different brain regions associated with empathy was quite droll. If you are a casual reader without a good background in the anatomy of the brain, I would suggest you get the "gist" of this chapter and skip it.

This was a very interesting book. There is also a test for you to fill in. I loved how he talked about the positive zero empathy and how he situated the surgeons on this spectrum. I hope one day he writes a book about people who score above average on the empathy test and how they function. Finally, I agree with him that the world should strive for more empathy and that this is the most important feature a human being can have.

Baron-Cohen's work attacks the notion of "evil" and states it is no longer a useful term. Instead, he argues, we should be assessing degrees of empathy, and understand that those with psychopathy, narcism, and borderline personality disorders and Asperger's syndrome have damaged empathy circuits. He discusses these various personality types and how they function, or fail to function, and how they differ in empathy.

A quick enjoyable read, but left me wanting much more. He opened up a lot to think about, but never went down the trail(s) very far. *At the time of finishing this book, the ending note on the conflict between Israel and Palestine is fitting. Though I find myself highly skeptical of his conclusion that adding empathy will solve the conflict. He overlooks the biggest variable of all. Also the most stubborn. The religious and sacred aspect of it.

A quick read exploring reasons why people behave badly. While it makes some interesting points and primarily has an overall emphasis on empathy, which I am all for, it quickly becomes a dry read and could delve deeper into it's own examples. As it is, I am glad it is a short book, but I would have preferred something with a bit more depth and better writing, as there were too many times this book just rapid fired off regurgitated facts.

The book has an appealing cover and title that I cannot help getting and reading it. It attempts to investigate the impacts of low empathy on cruelty in humans. Unfortunately, it is not logically and well-written, questions are left unanswered, transitions between ideas are hard to follow. I don't feel better-off or think I know more about empathy after reading this book. The only good point is that I feel intrigued to know more about the topic of cruelty and EQ as a measurement of empathy.

Fantastic for Psych students! If you want some light-reading during the summer break or in-between terms/semesters, to keep the academia rolling through your head, this is a MUST. As a lover of research as well as literature reviews, this is the perfect combination. Baron-Cohen introduced me to various psychologists, and their work, that I had not encountered before. Easy to follow, and was a very useful resource for my undergrad dissertation.

The first 2/3 of this, where Baron-Cohen is describing the various disorders with diminished empathy as one of the hallmarks, are very absorbing. Unfortunately, the last third, where he is riffing on ways to to be more accepting of people with such disorders, is less of a compelling read. Still, interesting stuff and worth 3 stars overall.

The only part that is difficult for the layman to grasp is when the author discusses the different parts of the hypothetical empathy circuit. In the end, one comes away with a picture that is only slightly more enlightened on the neuroscience than before. The clinical studies and psychological stuff makes intuitive sense but doesn't seem as substantial as one might like.

I haven't read this in quite awhile, but from what I remember it was an OKAY book. It didn't reveal any epiphanies or present a new method of understanding the topics it presented to discuss, which is what I kind of look for in books that deal with psychology or other social sciences studying human behavior and society and whatnot.

I enjoyed this book, and was very much interested in the case studies, but I feel as if this book should have been published as a paper (or multiple papers) in a journal. To make it a book, I feel like it should have been more extensive and applicable to a more general public. Liked the book, will suggest it to others.

One of the most intellectually exciting books I've read in a long time. Whether you are interested in philosophy, science, medicine or serial killers, you'll find that this book takes the experience of empathy and explores not only the psychological aspects, but also the physical changes which take place in the brain.

I thoroughly enjoyed the book. I likes how throughout the book, the author would summaroze what was said and even reference earlier things to really educate its audience. The empathy pathway and talk about specific parts of the brain was too much for me but I don't think that hindered my understanding of the book. I would galdly reread this in the future.

Offers a crystal clear understanding of human empathy levels. Could be better if these levels were the focus of the book, it is not. I liked the theory, description of good / evil by high empathy / lack of empathy, I felt the explanation to be Ockham's Razor. But I felt rather uneasy because of the theory's lack of elegance. Still very good read.

Good book. Covers the brain structure involved in the lack of empathy (which is evil defined)...both in the positive end(as in autism and Asperger's) and negative side (9as in Borderline Personality Disorder, Psychopathy, and anti-social/Narcissism.).Not as well supported with psychological studies/research as Zimbardo's "The Lucifer Effect"--but still a good read.

I loved it. It made me realize that I am actually quite an empathetic person (I was not sure about that before) and that I should read more on this topic. The language is easy to follow, as are the studies. The author makes a really good point about ”evil” and its meaning in the world in the 21st century.

A good deal of interesting content, including results of scientific research and some intriguing philosophical speculation. Not particularly well-written, in my opinion. I found many parts that contained very worthwhile content also displayed very dull writing. If the topic interests you, this book is worth the effort but just finishing it does require more effort than it need have.

I do like a scientific book that is straight-forward and readable. In the past I've been thrown by comments I've heard about Baron-Cohen's approach to autism, but in this volume it made sense to me.I was particularly pleased by his inclusion of emotions in his description of an experiment he conducted. It's good to read "imagine our excitement when..." coming from a scientist.
